When John Maloof bought a box of old photo negatives at an estate auction, he had no idea he was about to discover the mystery of Vivian Maier. Maloof was looking for pictures to use in a book about the Portage Park neighborhood in Chicago, USA. Instead, he found 30,000 images taken by Maier, a street photographer known for her amazing ability to capture interesting moments. Since then, Maloof has built a collection of Maier’s life and work. In his home attic, he keeps her cameras, 2,000 rolls of film, 3,000 prints, and 100,000 negatives, along with many 8mm movies and audiotapes. 

One morning, Maloof looked around at everything he had found. He felt he was on the edge of something special, and it all happened by chance. “When I bought all this, I had no idea what it was,” Maloof said. “I’m a third-generation flea market seller and could have easily sold it all to someone else.” For a while, Maloof and his friend Anthony Rydzon have been trying to learn more about Maier’s life. They spoke to families who had hired her as a nanny and talked to people at the shop where she developed her film. 

Maier was born in 1926 in New York and spent much of her childhood in France. In 1951, she returned to New York and in 1956 moved to Chicago to work as a nanny. Maier was known to be a private person but had a unique personality. She always carried a camera with her and wore large coats, wide-brimmed hats, and sturdy shoes. “On her day off, the camera would be around her neck, and we wouldn’t see her again until late at night,” said Maren Baylaender, whose husband employed Maier to care for his daughter. “I remember her as a private person but one who had strong opinions about movies and politics.” 

Maier knew a lot about theater and movies. Although she was not very social, she would walk the streets with her camera and talk to people, some of whom she interviewed on audiotape. She seemed to be very dedicated to her “second job” of documenting the world around her. “She was a true artist who followed her dreams,” said Rydzon. “She didn’t let anyone or anything stop her.” 

Maier’s work is a pure form of art; she did not create it for money. Her images often focus on women, children, the elderly, the poor, and abstract scenes. “What is interesting about Vivian is that she has so many captivating pictures,” said photography expert Larry Silverman. He sees influences from other photographers in her work and wonders if she developed her own style. “Was Vivian very skilled, or did she take ideas from those who came before her?” 

Maloof often thinks about whether he will ever go through all the negatives, which he keeps in three tall, fireproof file cabinets. The funny thing is that he had no real interest in photography until he found Maier’s work. Inspired by her architectural photos, Maloof started taking his own pictures. “As I improved as a photographer and revisited her work, I realized that the cityscapes were not what mattered to her. It’s the people, the street scenes, and the overall composition,” he said. “There was so much more to this work than I thought, and I realized I was sitting on something more important than I ever imagined. Now our goal is to share her name and get Vivian Maier into the history books.”

When a novel is called ambitious, it often means it has not completely succeeded. However, this is not the case with Eleanor Catton’s book, *The Luminaries*. I interviewed her in the UK when her book was very popular, and she seemed calm, especially since she was still in her twenties. She had just arrived from Germany and was flying back to New Zealand the next day. She shared a story about being stopped at passport control and asked to prove she was a writer. She pressed her novel against the glass. The official looked at it and asked, “What’s it about?” This is not an easy question for an author. 

*The Luminaries* is set in New Zealand during the 1860s. A series of crimes have happened, and a group of 12 men has come together to solve them. The story becomes very complex. Catton said she wanted to write a murder mystery, not a historical novel, but she found that the past gave her more chances for complications and misunderstandings for her characters. At over 800 pages, the book is “big by necessity” because she wanted to give each of the 20 main characters a good chance to shine.

When I asked her how it feels to be so successful at a young age, she answered in a thoughtful way. “It’s nice coming from a small country like this because everyone feels like the success is partly theirs. There’s a family-like feeling at home; I got a lot of praise from other people’s grandmas.” She also mentioned that it annoys her when people think her book is not a serious work.

“I wanted to write the book in the shape of a spiral,” Catton explained. “Each part is half the length of the part before it.” The story speeds up as it goes along. I asked if it matters whether readers notice these patterns. “I wanted to create a book with patterns that didn’t matter, but if you cared, you could find them in the book.” 

Despite its unique structure, *The Luminaries* is still an exciting murder mystery with a gripping plot. Surprisingly, she said she did not know how the story would end before she wrote it. “I would try to write myself into a corner and then see how creative I could be to get out of that situation.” One of her goals was to make the book enjoyable for readers.

We also talked about her love for television dramas. I asked if she might be interested in writing for TV. “That could be pretty cool,” she replied. She spoke with excitement and laughed softly. She lights up when discussing her writing and New Zealand. “I notice when I come to Britain how much my imagination changes just by being in a different place. I understand why writers leave New Zealand for busy cities to be around more people.” But for now, New Zealand will still be her home. I hope it continues to inspire her for many more novels.

As a boy, Jonny Kinkead spent his time either making things in his dad’s garage or playing the guitar. For the last forty years, he has been building steel-string acoustic guitars by hand. “I am still amazed by the guitar,” he says. “How can two pieces of wood create such a beautiful sound? And using different types of wood can change the sound too. It still surprises me.”

Jonny learned to play his brother’s guitar when he was eleven. When he turned sixteen, he wanted to learn the bass guitar. “Some people would get a part-time job to save money for one,” he says. “But I thought if you wanted something, you should make it yourself. I studied guitars and learned how different shapes and types of wood affect the sound.”

The bass guitar was the first instrument Jonny built from scratch, but he and his brothers had been making model boats and airplanes for a long time. “We drew designs and then built them, so I knew how to do it. My father taught us how to use tools like saws and chisels. I had also been fixing instruments for my friends.”

Jonny’s bass guitar turned out well, but he didn’t think about making guitars as a career at that time. He was also interested in painting and sculpture. After finishing school, he decided to study architecture at university because it involved design, which he liked. However, halfway through the course, he dropped out. “I was too independent for it,” he says. “But I left with a better idea of what I wanted to do. I was still interested in sculpture, but I realized that building guitars is a type of sculpture too – it shapes sound. I thought it might be a more practical career than pure art because I would be making things that people use.”

Since then, Jonny has made guitars for a living. For the first ten years, he also cleaned windows part-time to earn extra money. The first guitars he sold were only for the cost of materials, but as he became known as one of the best guitar-makers, he could charge more. Even now, almost forty years later, Jonny says he is “still scratching a living.” He admits he can only make about ten guitars a year, which limits his income.

In the early years, it was important for him to get known. He would go to music festivals most weekends to let musicians try his guitars and talk about him to their friends. He also had to learn how to price his instruments because he didn’t naturally think about money.

Jonny believes it is easier for new guitar-makers in the UK today. “When I started, many people thought only American-made acoustic guitars were good,” he says. “UK-made guitars were not seen as real, even though we have always had good instrument-making courses here. Now, our hand-made guitars have the reputation they deserve.”

Jonny thinks new instrument-makers should take courses to learn valuable techniques. However, he also believes that learning through trial and error is important. “You should look at other instruments, see what works and what doesn’t, and try different things,” Jonny says. “If you make the back too thin or too thick, it won’t sound good. If you learn from someone else, you may only learn one way, but if you teach yourself, like I did, you learn everything.”

Text: "When we talk about English conversation, we often start with the weather. This is a common tradition, and I will mention the famous saying by the 18th-century writer Dr. Johnson: 'When two Englishmen meet, their first talk is of the weather.' This saying is still true today, just as it was over two hundred years ago. However, many people stop here or try to explain why the English are 'obsessed' with the weather, but they often get it wrong. They think that when we talk about the weather, we are really interested in it. 

For example, the American writer Bill Bryson says that English weather is not interesting at all. He points out that in England, we do not have extreme weather like tornadoes or big storms, which makes it less exciting. On the other hand, the English broadcaster Jeremy Paxman disagrees with Bryson. He believes that English weather is interesting because it is unpredictable. He says that while we may not have tropical storms, living on the edge of an ocean means we can never be sure what the weather will be like.

From my research, I believe that both Bryson and Paxman miss the main point. Our conversations about the weather are not really about the weather itself. Instead, talking about the weather is a way for English people to connect with each other. For example, when someone says, 'Nice day, isn’t it?' or 'Ooh, isn’t it cold?' they are not really asking about the weather. These phrases are just ways to start a conversation or fill a pause.

Talking about the weather is similar to how monkeys groom each other. They spend time grooming, even when they are clean, to bond socially. There are specific situations where we use weather talk. Some people say that the English talk about the weather all the time, but that is not true. There are three main situations for weather talk: as a greeting, as a way to start a conversation, or as a topic to fill silence when other topics run out. 

This is why it seems like English people talk about the weather a lot. A conversation might start with a weather greeting, then move to more weather talk, and return to it when there is a pause. This can make it seem like we are obsessed with the weather."

Text: Alice Leader was standing in front of Hadrian’s Wall in Britain, trying to explain to her class of 12- and 13-year-olds how amazing it was that the Romans built something 120 km long and 5 meters high about 1900 years ago. The students were interested in this trip, choosing it over exciting tours to Spain, Greece, or France. However, they really wanted to know why the wall was built, and Alice felt her answers were not good enough. When she could not find a suitable historical novel to help her explain life at the Wall during Roman times, she decided to write one herself. After teaching for 31 years, Alice started her new career as an author in 2001. She felt that writing was a big change for her. “Teaching is like acting; it’s a performance every day and very demanding. Writing is exciting and a bit scary, but it’s not as tiring. My former teaching colleagues envy me because I still connect with children through my stories,” Alice says. 

Alice wants her novels to fill a gap in children’s fiction today. “Many young adult books focus on negative experiences. They are well written, but often they are dark or completely fantasy, like Harry Potter. My books are different.” Alice always tried to teach English and History together, like lessons about ancient Greece alongside the novel Tale of Troy. She loves the moment when a child goes from being bored to interested and then from not understanding to understanding. “I enjoy having bored children because it challenges me to make them interested,” she explains. 

Alice was inspired to write her first novel because she saw a gap in the market, but she also felt the change coming as her two sons were leaving home. Her head teacher suggested she take a creative writing course, which surprised her. “I had been teaching for 25 years. She said it would be good for me, but I didn’t want to spend my summer on a course I didn’t think I needed.” Before she could join the course, she had to send the tutors her best piece of writing, which she only learned about a few days before leaving. “I sat down at the computer and quickly created a story about a Roman couple and their baby-to-be.” Three hours and 30 pages later, she sent it in and was accepted right away. During the course, other students reviewed her work and encouraged her to publish it. 

With only 8,000 report cards as proof of her writing skills, apart from that one story, she asked her head teacher for a year off to write her first novel. It helped that her husband, Zachary Leader, is a critic and editor. His help in editing the novel was very important. Alice says, “My mother-in-law thinks we are rival authors, but I believe we work well together. He improves what I write – he reads a chapter and changes the sentence structure, and if something isn’t working, he suggests different words. My instinct is to keep adding more scenes. That’s the difference between a fiction writer and an editor.”

To raise money for charity, a newspaper and a TV company challenged brothers Jonny and Alistair Brownlee, who are champion triathletes, to take part in a special race. This race would have Jonny racing in a car on the roads, while Alistair would race on a mountain bike across the countryside. The race took place in the beautiful and hilly Yorkshire Dales in northern England. 

“I’m looking forward to it,” Jonny said at the start line. “I’ve never done anything like this before: it’s exciting! These roads have beautiful views, and it’s very cold, so I’ll be warm in the car.” Alistair was also excited, but he was dressed in full winter cycling gear, unlike Jonny, who wore jeans and a sweatshirt. “To be honest,” Alistair said, “I’ve seen his driving before, so I’m not sure he’ll make it. I might just stop for a cup of tea halfway up.”

The race started at Semerwater lake in Wensleydale and would finish at Fleet Moss, Yorkshire’s highest road, which is about 350 meters high. This would be easy for the car, but Alistair had to climb a steep hill right at the beginning. After a quick handshake, they were off. Alistair quickly rode away on his bike, while Jonny got into his car and started driving. The big question was: who would reach the finish line first?

Jonny’s confidence quickly faced a challenge. Just 15 seconds into his drive, he encountered a giant tractor blocking the road. “Welcome to Yorkshire,” he said to the cameraman in his car. “If Alistair beats me, it’s all because of this farmer!” After getting past the tractor, Jonny continued driving, while Alistair struggled with the steep hill. A few miles in, he had to get off his bike and carry it up the hill, passing walls and fences. Sheep watched curiously as the Olympic champion carried his bike.

Finally, Alistair reached the top of the hill. With the sun shining and open land ahead, he began to pick up speed. Meanwhile, Jonny faced another challenge. The narrow roads in the villages of Yorkshire were not made for fast driving. He had to slow down to get around a very tight corner and then drove through a stream on the road. Once he was clear of the last village, he raced straight towards the finish line.

Neither brother knew how close the other was. As Jonny sped through the final stretch to Fleet Moss, Alistair was racing across his last field and back onto the road. He pushed hard, and then suddenly had to brake as he reached the finish line. Looking up, he asked the crowd, “Is he here?” When they said no, he raised his arms in celebration, shouting, “Yes!”

A few moments later, Jonny arrived in his car and stepped out. “Well done,” he said, feeling disappointed. “I’m gutted.”

Text: 'The silence is what you notice when you play on Centre Court at the Wimbledon tennis championships. You bounce the ball quietly on the soft grass; you toss it up to serve; you hit it and hear the echo of your own shot. The trimmed grass, the rich history, the old stadium, the players in white, and the respectful crowds all create a special atmosphere that keeps you focused. The quiet of Centre Court helps my game. What I find hardest in a tennis match is to block out everything except the game and the point I’m playing. The silence is broken by loud applause and cheers when a point ends. I hear them, but it feels distant. I don’t realize that there are fifteen thousand people watching me closely, or that millions are watching around the world as I play Roger Federer in the 2008 Wimbledon final – the biggest match of my life. I had always dreamed of playing at Wimbledon. My uncle Toni, who has been my coach since I was young, taught me that this is the biggest tournament. By the time I was 14, I was sharing with my friends my dream of playing there one day and winning. Before 2008, I had played and lost to Federer twice – in the final the year before and the year before that. The loss in 2006 was not too hard. I was just happy to have made it that far after turning twenty. Federer won easily, but my loss in 2007 was much harder. I knew I could have played better; it was not my skill that failed me, but my mindset. I cried for half an hour in the dressing room after that loss. Losing always hurts, but it hurts more when you have a chance and lose it. Toni, my tough coach, usually does not comfort me, even when I win. It shows how upset I was that he told me there was no reason to cry and that there would be more Wimbledons and finals. I told him he didn’t understand; I thought that was my last chance to win. I know how short a professional athlete's career is, and I want to make the most of it. Every moment counts, but some moments are more important than others, and I had let a big one slip away in 2007. There was nothing Toni could do to help me feel better. But he was right in the end. Another chance came my way. Here I was again in 2008, just one year later. I was confident I had learned from my defeat the year before; this time, my mindset would be strong. The best sign that I was ready was my belief that I would win. At dinner with family and friends the night before the final, we didn’t talk about the match. I didn’t tell them not to mention it, but they understood that I was already focused on the match in my mind. From that moment until the match started, that focus was mine alone.'

Text: In early April 1957, a young and hopeful Englishwoman arrived in Africa. In her first letter home, she wrote, “I am living in the Africa I have always longed for.” Her name was Jane Goodall, and she would spend most of her life in Africa as a citizen, journalist, scientist, activist, and environmentalist. In 1963, the National Geographic Society helped make her famous by publishing articles and making documentaries about her research on chimpanzees. Her fame grew with her own writing, including popular children’s books and the 1971 bestseller *In the Shadow of Man*, which has been translated into 47 languages and is still available today. Jane Goodall is one of the most celebrated female scientists of the 20th century, second only to Marie Curie. However, her fame sometimes overshadows her real achievements. Many articles and interviews tell her life story, but they often focus on her personal life rather than her work. She has been portrayed in many ways: as a girl seeking adventure, a privileged woman who wanted to live with wild animals, and a strong feminist in a male-dominated field. These images can undervalue her true contributions. 

Based on the number of references to her research by other scientists, the success of her students, and the data collected during her forty-year study, Jane Goodall should be recognized as a leading figure in her field and the world’s top zoologist. Simply put, she helped us understand the social and emotional lives of chimpanzees. Before Goodall’s work, people misunderstood the dangers of wild chimpanzees. No one knew that chimpanzees ate meat or that they used tools, like humans. We also did not realize that chimpanzees share similar emotions with us or that their social structures are very much like ours. Goodall discovered that chimpanzee communities in Africa have their own unique cultural traditions. Her book, *The Chimpanzees of Gombe* (1986), is the most important work in chimpanzee research and serves as an encyclopedia on the subject. Her long-term study of wild chimpanzees in Gombe State, Nigeria, is considered one of the great scientific achievements of the Western world. Jane Goodall changed how we study animals, and since chimpanzees are our closest relatives, she also changed how we view ourselves.

Even as a child, there were signs of the person Jane Goodall would become. One clear example happened in the autumn of 1939 when she was just five years old. One day, Jane disappeared, and her family called the police to help find her. After a long search, she reappeared alone, with straw in her hair and clothes. When her mother asked where she had been, Jane explained that she wanted to know how hens lay eggs. To find out, she had crawled into a henhouse, hidden in the straw, and stayed very still for five hours until a hen laid an egg. This moment can be seen as the start of her journey as a biologist.

Text: 

In our first hour-long conversation, Shirley Ford talks to me using the voice of a playful 8-year-old boy, a tired mother, a funny elderly Scottish woman, and a very fast-talking alien. Her voices are familiar to people who watch children’s TV shows and cartoons, as well as those who have seen training videos about health and safety. “I just did a voiceover about back injuries,” she says, “so I had to learn how to say many medical terms quickly.” 

Shirley explains what it takes to do voiceovers. “Many actors, even famous ones, think they can do funny voices, and many probably can,” she says. “But there is more to it. You need to bring the script to life for an audience that can’t see you. You wouldn’t believe how many well-known people want to do voiceover work. Producers invite them to auditions because of their fame, but often they don’t get the roles because they are used to acting with their whole bodies.”

After school, Shirley joined a drama course, hoping for a traditional acting career. During the course, she occasionally worked singing jingles for TV ads. “One day,” she says, “the man who ran the recording studio suggested I try out for the voice of a rabbit in a cartoon. It seemed silly – I hadn’t studied drama to play rabbits – but I tried it for fun and, surprisingly, got a major role.” Shirley discovered she could do voices and thought voiceover work might be a good path for her. “Things just happened for me,” she says. “In my second film, I was lucky to play the main character, her brother, and her mother.”

Adult female actors are often asked to provide the voices for young boys and girls. Their voices are lighter than those of male actors, and hiring child performers involves complicated procedures and many forms, which production companies prefer to avoid. Shirley has learned to create different sounds and to avoid always sounding like the same child. She collects new voices by watching children’s TV. 

Cartoons are the best part of her job, which also includes educational videos and vacuum cleaner ads. “Those are tough because you have to sound excited about something you don’t care about, but my years in this job help,” she says. “I’ve learned that the trick is to smile while you talk – it makes your voice sound bright and cheerful. When I have days doing animation work, it feels like a holiday; working with other actors makes a big difference.”

The competition for work is strong, and a good showreel – a recording that shows what the artist can do – is very important. “It’s worth investing in a strong showreel,” Shirley says. “There are agencies that help voiceover artists create them.” She believes she has reached the top of her profession through hard work as much as talent. “Whether it’s making your showreel and taking it to film and TV companies, advertising agencies, and recording studios, or just practicing your voices, it’s all about setting goals and not giving up.”

For anyone thinking about a career in voiceovers, Shirley suggests attending “specialist workshops – they cover all types of voiceover.” She also thinks a love for human sound is essential, describing herself as obsessed with voices and becoming the characters she plays. “If I’ve been in the studio doing a specific American voice, for example, it can take over me, and I’ll be speaking like that for hours, maybe even days,” she says. “My children have grown up hearing their mom talk in many different voices.”

Text: "People often ask me how I became a cartoonist. This is understandable because cartooning is a job many children dream about, like being a race car driver. However, most people eventually give up these childhood dreams and think about more practical jobs, like being a tax lawyer or making car parts. The idea that you can earn a living by drawing simple pictures, like the doodles in school notebooks, seems silly. Yet, some people do just that. 

People become cartoonists in different ways, but most have wanted to do it for a long time. For me, I had a typical childhood for a cartoonist. I loved comic strips, contributed to school publications, and was known as 'the kid who draws.' I studied graphic design in college and, after graduating, I showed my illustrations to different companies. I was lucky to find someone at a newspaper who needed political cartoons about local issues. I created a few ideas, and they bought them. In a few months, I was making enough money to support myself.

You don’t need much to become a cartoonist. You don’t need a university degree, a lot of money, or even to be a great artist. You just need your brain, your hand, and something to draw with. But if it were that easy, there would be as many cartoonists as there are teachers. The barriers to becoming a cartoonist are low, but it is still a tough job. No one should try to become a cartoonist unless they feel they cannot do anything else. It is much easier to get a regular job that pays the bills and allows time for family, home repairs, and hobbies.

The more skills you have, the better chance you have of making a living with your art. I have created political cartoons, comic strips, and comic books. I have also worked as a writer, caricaturist, and designer. I don’t refuse any work because you can learn a lot from jobs you may not want to do. It also helps to be intelligent, well-read, and curious about the world.

What about the business side of being a cartoonist? In the past, many cartoonists could find regular jobs with different newspapers and magazines. But those days are fading. Today, cartooning is often an entrepreneurial activity, which means you not only have to create the work but also sell it. The more comfortable you are with this, the better you will do. I have seen cartoonists with average creativity and great business skills succeed more than those who are very talented but lack other skills.

It surprises me how often I meet people who have never sold a cartoon and are afraid someone will steal their ideas. Some are so worried that they won’t even let others see their work! Legally, to protect your work, you just need to draw a small ‘c’ for ‘copyright,’ circle it, and write your name and the date next to it. But honestly, it is more likely that no one will be interested in your work. If someone does steal a cartoon and it becomes popular online, it is not a disaster – it can actually be a lucky break!"

Text: "Twenty years ago, I was moving to a new house and cleaning out my things. Among other items, I decided to throw away an electric guitar that my dad had given me for my 16th birthday. It was a sleek, black guitar made in Japan. I usually hate getting rid of old things, so why did I want to throw this one away? I took it to the dump and was about to leave it on a pile of rubbish when a young man approached me, looking confused. 'You’re not going to throw that away, are you?' he asked. I told him I was, and I started to feel regret. He asked if he could have it, and I said 'Yes.' After that, I felt sad about my decision for many years.

Then, a few months ago, I opened an email that changed my life. I remembered a story about a man who lost his wedding ring in the ocean and found it ten years later in a fish he was eating. That’s how I felt when I read the email from someone I didn’t know, a guitar dealer named Keith Rushton. He told me, 'I’ve got your electric guitar.' It had been bought and sold many times since the young man at the dump took it. Keith found a name-and-address label on the back of the guitar. He realized it was probably old, but he used my name to find me online. He contacted me through the newspaper I work for and offered to sell it back to me. I was so emotional; I would have given him anything, but his price was very fair. I had forgotten that my dad always put name-and-address stickers on my things, including my guitar. My dad would have laughed at this strange situation!

My parents wanted me to learn classical guitar because it was popular in the 1970s. I loved the sound of it; it was calming and gentle. Unlike the violin, it didn’t sound bad when a beginner played it. But I struggled to improve, so I switched to the electric guitar and played easier songs. This was also the time of punk music, when people who couldn’t play well could still be rock stars. When I opened the box that Keith sent me with my old guitar, I suddenly remembered my birthday in 1978 when my smiling parents gave it to me. Holding it again felt smooth and smaller than I remembered. I sat down to play, but then I wanted to stand up and put a strap over my shoulder because electric guitars are played that way. My fingers remembered where to go. I couldn’t draw the chords, but my hands just knew what to do. My middle-aged fingers felt the familiar pain of pressing down the strings to play a chord. The electric guitar is not really a solo instrument. Now that I’m learning it again, I think I’ll need to form a band. My son is learning the saxophone; maybe we can play together. Or maybe I can find other people my age who have had a similar experience. We could call ourselves 'The Regainers!'"

Text: 

There has been a lot of discussion about sleep recently. When I wrote the book *Insomniac*, which is about people who cannot sleep, I felt like I was one of the few warning about the dangers of not getting enough sleep and how it affects our minds, bodies, and moods. Anyone who has trouble sleeping will tell you that sleep is very important for our mental, physical, and social health. Those who struggle the most with sleep often understand its importance the best. It is good that sleep is finally getting the attention it deserves. However, I wonder about dreams. I haven’t heard much about them in this discussion. We are losing our dreams all the time. When you wake up early because of an alarm, you miss out on the last hour or two of sleep, which is mostly REM (Rapid Eye Movement) sleep, the stage where we have the most dreams. Our most vivid and powerful dreams happen mainly in REM sleep just before we wake up in the morning. A good sleeper spends about a quarter of their sleep time in REM, so a person who lives to be 90 years old will spend six or seven years in this stage. When researchers prevent people from having REM sleep, they find that the next night, people have more REM sleep to make up for it. This suggests that dreams serve a purpose. 

When researchers discovered REM sleep in 1953, many agreed with the famous psychologist Sigmund Freud, who believed that understanding dreams was the best way to understand our minds. However, later research did not support this idea. The focus of dream studies shifted from psychological reasons to physical ones. Currently, there is very little agreement among dream researchers, according to Harvard sleep scientist Robert Stickgold. 

Dreams are important. At a meeting of the Associated Professional Sleep Society, P.F. Pagel from the University of Colorado Medical School shared a study that found that actors, writers, and directors remember and use their dreams much better than others. He concluded that the use of dreams increases with a person’s interest in creativity. It makes sense that filmmakers have a strong connection to their dreams, as film is very dream-like. But I wondered, are only creative people the ones who benefit from their dreams? Don’t teachers, software designers, and politicians also need to think creatively? 

Stickgold says that dreams help us connect ideas in new and surprising ways, using knowledge from the past and present to create new associations. Dreams may help us discover new patterns and combinations that break our usual ways of thinking. For example, Stickgold found that when people are woken from REM sleep and asked to respond to a word, their answers are more original than when they are woken from other sleep stages. They “ignore the obvious and connect things in unexpected ways... This is what creativity is,” says Stickgold. 

I find that I write better when I wake up from intense dreams. Even a difficult dream, or one I can barely remember, seems to give me ideas and inspiration. On those days, words and images come to me so quickly that I can hardly keep up with typing. I don’t know how it works, but it does seem to help. However, creativity is not just for writers or artists. We live in a complex world, and we all need our brains to work well. We need to think creatively and flexibly as we interact with colleagues, family, and friends. This is why dreaming is important.

Twenty years ago, Susie Ray left London to live in a small coastal town in south-west England. When you enter her studio, you see a beautiful view of the sea and many empty frames on the walls, along with smiling photos of her two daughters. Susie is a well-known copyist artist, able to recreate famous paintings from the early 20th century and the 16th century. It seems strange that she doesn’t keep any of her own work. “I don’t have any of my own around,” Susie says with a shrug. “As soon as I finish them, they go.” 

Susie is in high demand. Over her 30 years as a copyist, she has painted works by many great artists, including Renoir, Monet, and Van Gogh. Her copies are so accurate that art experts sometimes mistake them for the originals. While the original paintings can sell for millions, her copies sell for a few hundred pounds to £12,000, depending on how long she spends on them. Susie does not reveal most of her clients, but they include galleries and private collectors. Some collectors are true art lovers, but others care more about status. One famous buyer likes to show off his “Van Gogh” painting, which is actually a “Susie Ray Van Gogh.” “Many famous people pass off my copies as originals,” she says. “That’s their choice.” Some collectors keep the original in a bank safe and display Susie’s copy to save on insurance.

Susie is honest about her work. When she copies an old masterpiece, she tries to make it look as real as possible because she believes it is important to respect the original artist. However, she signs her name on the back of the canvas. Selling a copy as the real thing is illegal, and even though she knows people who have done that, she has never been tempted. Those who make fakes often get into trouble. Susie points out that she isn’t rich and has faced challenges, but her situation is better now, and she doesn’t want to risk her reputation.

Susie didn’t always work as a copyist. After earning her art degree, she worked as an illustrator for a botanical garden for several years, earning very little money. Looking back, she sees that this experience helped her develop her skills and gave her a love for plants, even though it was hard to live on that income. She had to be very precise and get things right the first time. She has no regrets about that job but is happy to have found something more financially rewarding.

When younger artists ask Susie for advice, she tells them to learn to draw well and represent things accurately. She emphasizes how much she has studied to do her work. Her training allows her to draw plants, make perfect copies of 15th-century paintings, and reproduce 20th-century abstract art, but she now focuses on French impressionists, especially Manet, Cezanne, and Degas. 

Susie believes that many people think modern art is easy, almost like children’s art. However, she explains that impressionists painted quickly and freely, but they were also very careful. This combination is harder to achieve than people think. Given her skills, it seems unusual that Susie doesn’t create her own art. Isn’t art about expressing yourself? Could a Susie Ray original be worth more than a copy? She explains that her work is the result of years of training, and she makes a good living from it. She has tried creating her own art, like oil paintings of fishing nets, but they looked too much like photographs—fine, but not special. It’s like living on simple food after enjoying meals from a top chef. Susie is a perfectionist.

Text: 'During her racing days, Ellen MacArthur cared most about the sea and being the fastest person on it. This passion started in her childhood. She had a special connection with the boats that took her around the world; they felt like one with her. When she returned to land, everyday life seemed unimportant. People wanted to know about her races, but she quickly wanted to be back on the ocean, challenging nature, even in places that had almost defeated her. After finishing second in the Vendée Globe, a solo round-the-world race, she showed me the small, stuffy cabin of her boat, Kingfisher. This was her home, workplace, and survival space for 94 days. She explained how she carefully planned everything, even counting the exact number of kitchen paper rolls she would need. Preparation was key for her. She proudly displayed her unappealing stock of foil-wrapped, freeze-dried food, a tiny gas stove, and organized medical supplies. Her care for the boat was as impressive as her sailing skills. The boat was her world, and she took care of it because her life depended on it. Now, she views the world as a boat: a small, beautiful, and fragile thing with limited resources. 

Her turning point came during a trip to South Georgia, a remote island in the South Atlantic, where she helped with a bird survey on albatrosses. This experience made her reflect and see things differently. The many abandoned whaling stations served as a warning to her. She felt that humans often take what they want and move on without thinking. When I arrived at Ellen’s office, she was finishing a heated conference call. She then explained why we must act now to save the planet. 'We are not making coal, oil, or gas anymore. They are precious resources we have only once. We need to find ways to not waste them. At first, my message was negative – to use less – but I realized there is a better way to think about it.' Now, she focuses on re-using materials, passionately discussing things like reusable industrial carpet tiles. For the past three years, she has been visiting factories, mines, and power stations, talking to governments and businesses about our dependence on non-renewable resources. 'I will never be an expert,' she says. 'But I am like a sponge. I love learning. The current situation is something I cannot ignore. Compared to sailing, this feels less selfish. It’s about finding how my voice can be most helpful. It really matters.' She also started the Ellen MacArthur Foundation, a charity that works with businesses and schools to help young people imagine and create a sustainable future. 'I do miss the adventure of being at sea,' she says. 'It defines who I am. You feel connected to everything around you. You don’t have time to feel lonely. You focus on records, practical matters, and survival. My new message is not as simple as saying: “I’m going to be the fastest around the world.” I may have been the fastest, but this work is more important than anything I’ve ever done.'

Jordan Romero is 13 years old and wants to be the youngest person to climb Mount Everest. If he succeeds, he could become one of the most famous teenagers of his time. He hopes to inspire other kids to go outside and explore, instead of just playing on computers and video games. Jordan's climbing team includes his father, Paul, and mother, Karen. They call themselves "Team Romero." Climbing Everest is just part of their plan. If Jordan climbs Everest and Vinson Massif in Antarctica, he will be the youngest person to climb the Seven Summits, which are the highest mountains on each continent. Very few people achieve this before they turn thirty. Jordan has already climbed five of these mountains and might finish before he becomes a teenager.

I spoke to several experienced Everest climbers, and none of them thought it was a good idea to take a 13-year-old up the highest mountain in the world. They agreed that a young climber might be strong enough physically, but they were not sure if a teenager would be emotionally ready. They also questioned whether a young person could have enough experience to make good decisions and react quickly while climbing safely.

The Romeros have heard these opinions before. Paul says, "I know there is criticism, but I can’t focus on it – we have a lot to do. I think about possible problems, of course. Karen and I always consider the risks, but we believe our experience as climbers will help. Watching Jordan grow gives me confidence. He is getting stronger and more mature."

I also wonder about Jordan’s reasons for wanting to climb. Is this just a father pushing his son to take risks? Paul insists, "This project isn’t about me wanting to be famous through my son’s achievements. At first, Jordan thought about doing this later in life, but we decided: ‘Why not now?’ We talk to him often to make sure he still wants to do it."

When I ask Jordan what he enjoys about the challenge, he says, "I just focus on reaching my goal." In the past, few people cared about being the youngest or fastest to climb a mountain or sail an ocean. Today, every adventure is shared online, and every climb becomes a record-setting event. The more exciting the record, the more attention it gets. This creates a problem for Jordan. While some people say that focusing on achievements can take away the fun, if Jordan wants to inspire others, he needs to engage with the media. This means blogging, taking photos, and giving interviews. He has to do something amazing, like climbing Everest.

Paul adds, "If Jordan comes home tomorrow and says he wants to stop climbing and play basketball instead, we will end this project and go to the gym."

**Simplified Text:**

When you see a teenager with an MP3 player, it’s likely they are not listening to classical music. Most people can name many pop groups, but if you ask my friends about Brahms, they usually don’t know who he is. I just started a music degree, but my classmates know as little about classical music as other people our age. If you don’t know who created the music, you probably don’t own any of their recordings. This is sad for fans of classical music. Last year, only 3% of concert tickets sold were for classical music events, and the average classical recording sells only about 300 copies. I find this hard to believe. 

So, why is there less interest in classical music, which has been around for centuries? Older people often blame our love for TV and video games, but I don’t think that’s the reason. The truth is that classical music doesn’t attract most people, especially teenagers, who are the ones most likely to buy music and concert tickets. I know some teenagers who enjoy classical concerts, but they are few. Even though I play in an orchestra, I’m not a big fan of classical music. I like many styles, but according to what’s on my computer, I listen to classical music about as much as that 3% figure suggests.

Why don’t teenagers like classical music? First, the pace and rhythm of classical music, with its many changes, can be hard for us. We like to talk, play, and think quickly. Experts say we can only pay attention for about three minutes, which is too short for most classical pieces but just right for pop songs. Pop music is simple and easy to listen to, while understanding classical music takes time and focus. Also, pop music often talks about things that interest teenagers, while classical music usually does not.

The way we listen to music has changed too. In the past, families would play music together at home, and playing an instrument was important. Now, you can find any music online, but classical music is rarely part of our daily lives. When was the last time you heard classical music in a store? One of my teachers says that more people are going to classical concerts now. Maybe, but I doubt many of them are teenagers. In my orchestra, we play classical music in many places, but when I look at the audience, I mostly see older people. I don’t know why more middle-aged people enjoy classical concerts, but I do know that if your parents love something, you might want to avoid it.

Some people say that schools are to blame for teenagers’ lack of interest in classical music, but many kids want to play classical music in their school orchestras. They come early to practice and stay late to rehearse. They enjoy classical music when they perform, but it’s not their favorite music otherwise. The two activities have become separate. When we want to relax, we usually choose pop music.

Bonnie Wyndham got out of her mother’s car and looked at Almonside School. “I’ll make you sorry I’ve come here,” she said with a smile. Her mother was getting out of the other side, so she didn’t hear, but Bonnie didn’t mind. Her mother knew how she felt. Mrs. Wyndham looked around. Almonside was a strange school, with buildings hidden among the trees on a hillside; it was confusing at first. Then she saw the signs: Science block, gymnasium, riding centre… “Riding centre,” Bonnie said, suddenly interested. “Headmaster’s study,” her mother replied. “This way.” Bonnie followed her mother along a wide path between the trees. “I wish you’d walk beside me instead of following me like a dog,” Mrs. Wyndham said tiredly, but she didn’t expect Bonnie to do so. A few minutes later, her mother was talking to Bonnie’s new headmaster in his study, while Bonnie waited outside the door. Suddenly, Bonnie stood up. “Why should I just sit here?” she thought. “I’ll be thrown out soon anyway, so why not get it over with?” She left the building and went to the riding centre, following the sign. There was a nice old building for the horses and a large area for indoor riding. Bonnie looked around, but there was no one in sight. She approached the horses with respect. They were well cared for, and she could see that right away. Almost every stall was occupied, and she walked along, looking carefully at each horse. “I know what you’re doing here,” she said to a small pony, gently touching its nose. The next horse made her stop. “But aren’t you the best of the lot!” she exclaimed. He was brown with a bit of white. He looked lively, which Bonnie liked. “You know, I feel like we’ve met before,” she said, stroking his neck. “It was in my dreams, and I was riding you to victory in a big competition…” Above the stall was his name: Maverick. Suddenly, she couldn’t resist the urge to ride him. “I wonder where I can find a bridle and a saddle. It can’t be far.” Bonnie was happy to find that the room with the riding equipment was unlocked. While she was busy putting a saddle on Maverick, she forgot all about her mother and the headmaster. When she sat high on the big horse outside, she felt like a queen, in charge of everything she could see. Her nickname at her old school had been Queen Bee, and she laughed as she remembered it. “You’re the best horse I’ve ever ridden, Maverick,” she said with admiration. “I’m not joking because I know about horses, even if I don’t know about anything else.” She nudged him into a walk, then into a trot. “If I stay here, I think you and I could be great friends,” she said. She went around and around the paddock. The rhythm was exciting, with a little breeze brushing past her cheek. She could tell Maverick trusted her, and she felt sure he would jump well.

Text: 'I’ve met Cody Simpson before and have always been impressed by his quiet confidence. The 15-year-old Australian has already released many successful songs. So how did a relaxed surfer end up on stage in front of thousands of fans? “I first picked up a guitar when I was six years old and started writing songs when I was seven,” Cody says, remembering how it all began. “But I was swimming and surfing every day. Those activities were more important to me back then; I had a busy life. When I was 13 and in high school, I posted a few videos online.” These videos changed everything. He started by posting a video of himself and a friend singing at a school concert. Fans left comments asking for more videos on their social media. So Cody, who had recorded more at home, was happy to share them. The responses were amazing. Cody was also a talented swimmer. He trained hard with great coaches and focused on his sport. But then record labels contacted him, and he had a tough choice: stay in Australia and keep swimming, or take a big risk by signing a deal and moving with his family to the US. Cody decided to take the chance. “It was very hard for me – especially at such a young age – to choose a career. Can you imagine being 12 or 13 years old and trying to decide what you want to do for the rest of your life?” He had to tell his swimming coach and friends that he was moving to the States. “It surprised most people. I’m kind of the quiet kid,” he says, remembering their shocked faces. “I’m very modest, and I think it’s important to stay that way in this crazy world.” So Cody packed his bags and moved with his family across the world, giving up one dream to try to make another come true. Although his family stays out of the spotlight and is not directly involved in his career, they support him from behind the scenes. Cody says it’s important to have a close group of good people around you to keep you grounded. Of course, everyone has doubts. “Sometimes when I’m alone, I think, ‘How did my decision affect my little brother and sister?’ My little brother is eight years old, and he’s traveling the world, doing school on the road; he doesn’t have a normal life,” Cody admits. “I worry about how that affects him, but my family always reassures me that they support me in everything I do.” Success in any career comes from being willing to say ‘yes’ to your big opportunity, even when it’s a little scary. “It all happened so fast and unexpectedly,” Cody says. “Now, I’m going to countries I never thought I’d visit and playing in front of hundreds of thousands of fans – it’s something many people dream of. But I know it won’t last forever.”'

Text: 

I jumped out of bed, pulled back a corner of the bedroom curtain, and looked down at the river bend. A new crack in the ice sparkled in the morning sunlight. I shaded my eyes and looked upstream at the sandbags, which were there to protect the buildings from flooding as the river ice melted. My back still hurt from lifting the sandbags into place. Last week, I had worked with most of the town’s adults for long hours, showing that I could do the job. My grandfather didn’t pay much attention to this. 

With one hand still on the curtain, I looked at the half-mile stretch of dark water created by the release pipe from the wood processing factory in Milltown. There were fragile ice shelves on either side, and solid ice further downstream. As I took off my pajamas and reached for my kayaking wetsuit, I saw a boy on the other side of the river. I didn’t recognize him. I frowned. He was trying to balance on an ice shelf near the warm water from the factory. I zipped up my wetsuit and grabbed my kayaking jacket. I checked the pocket for my lucky chain – a silver chain my famous grandfather brought back from South America. This chain is more special to me than having a famous grandfather, and only he, my mom, and I know about it. I also have the diary he kept on that trip, which I read before I sleep. I touched the chain again and went to the kitchen. 

“Good morning, Rex,” my mom smiled as I took a banana from the counter. “You’re up early for a Saturday. I’ll make brunch after your training session. Be careful.” 

“Thanks, Mom.” I walked down the hallway and almost bumped into my tall grandfather as he came out of his bedroom. 

“Can’t you watch where you’re going?” he shouted. “Where are you going?” 

“Sorry, Grandpa. I’m going kayaking.” It was obvious from my wetsuit, and he had seen me in my kayak every morning. I tried to ignore his anger, but it was getting harder. 

“What’s the point of training? You didn’t win the competition,” he said. His words hit me hard, but I took a deep breath and counted to three. He walked away and slammed the bathroom door. My mom came over with a sympathetic smile. 

“Don’t mind him. He’s…” 

“...not himself right now,” I finished for her. I didn’t say that he had always been like this. But like my mom, I tried to be understanding. When I was a child, he was my hero. He showed me photos of himself in National Geographic magazine. Those old photos still hang on his bedroom wall, above his dusty medals and trophies. But I don’t go into his room anymore. I have my own collection of trophies to look at, and maybe one day, my own face in National Geographic. Still, a part of me wants to stay loyal to him, this grumpy old man. 

My mom smiled. “At least he’s coming out of his bedroom more. Have a good session, Rex. I admire your determination to keep going, even on these cold days!” 

I smiled back as I peeled my banana. “It’ll be warmer in South America,” I said. “If I find sponsors for my expedition.” She laughed and went back to the kitchen. I finished my banana and went downstairs. Stepping into the backyard, I hurried towards the boathouse.

Text: 'Mum grabbed Jess by the arm. “Come with me,” she said. Jess followed her into the study, where on the table, leaning against the wall, was an unframed painting. It was clearly one of Grandpa’s works, but it looked different from his usual style and was obviously unfinished. “Do you know anything about this?” Mum asked. Jess shook her head. “I’ve never seen it before. I didn’t know he was working on anything.” 

Jess looked closely at the painting. There was a river that took up most of the picture; it was not a river she recognized and maybe it wasn’t real at all, just a made-up river. The painting was strange and beautiful in a mysterious way. The riverbank was very small, with just a hint of green that was easy to miss, drawing the eye into the pale waters and towards a hidden sea. There were no animals, no birds, and no people; it felt right that way. There seemed to be no place for living things in this distant scene. Yet for some reason, she was fascinated, thinking about autumn coming after a long summer.

Mum spoke again. “It has a name.” There was something in her voice that showed her excitement. Jess understood why. Grandpa never named his paintings. He just painted them and let others figure them out. Mum turned the painting over and pointed to the words Grandpa had written there. Jess read them aloud: “River Boy.” The words felt strangely important to her, but she didn’t know why. There was another mystery. She looked at Mum. “There is no boy.” 

“Exactly. Strange, isn’t it? For him to be so specific. But he hasn’t finished it yet, so maybe he will add the boy later. I made the mistake of asking him about it.” 

“Mum! You should have known better.” 

“I know, but I couldn’t help it. It’s such an unusual painting, especially with a name. You can guess his response.” 

Jess didn’t need to guess. She knew what Grandpa would have said. “He told you it’s not the artist’s job to explain a painting because each picture has its own life and language, just like a poem, and we either understand it or we don’t. He said painting is hard enough work without having to explain it to everyone…” 

“‘Ignoramus,’ he said.” 

“… every ignoramus what it means. And if artists had to explain their pictures to every Tom, Dick, and Harry, they’d never get any work done. And he said…” Mum interrupted her, laughing. “Something like that. Anyway, I was hoping you might know something about this painting since you seem to inspire him.” 

“Inspire?” 

“Someone who gives an artist ideas.” Jess knew what the word meant. Grandpa often used it when she watched him paint, but he usually said it to mean that the muse wasn’t helping him that day or that he needed to be nice to the muse because he had a hard part to work on. He never suggested that the muse was about her. In fact, she always thought he meant some kind of goddess, not a real person. It was hard to imagine anyone, even a goddess, influencing someone as stubborn as Grandpa. “He doesn’t need me to inspire him,” she said. “He’s been painting all his life.”'

Text: 'When I woke up this morning, I didn’t plan to cut a hole in my bedroom carpet. I’m not saying it was an accident, but it could have been. For example, if I had tripped over the edge of the bed while holding Dad’s Stanley knife, the blade might have gone into the carpet and made a big hole. I’m not saying that happened, just that it could have. I didn’t mean to damage the carpet. I didn’t wake up thinking, ‘Today I will cut a hole in my carpet.’ It just seemed like a good idea at the time, as things often do. Later, I wondered why I thought that, but by then it was too late. This happens to me quite often. I’m a bit unlucky in that way.

What I was really doing was trying to find a way to fit my corner cabinet into a corner. Gran gave me the cabinet when she moved from her house to a flat. It’s very cute! It’s small, painted white, with pink and blue flowers around the edge, and tiny glass doors. Gran used to keep china ornaments in there, like shepherdesses and milkmaids. I keep my collection of shells, fossils, and interesting stones in it. Gran knew I always loved her corner cabinet, and I was so happy when she gave it to me!

The problem is, it is a corner cabinet, which means it has to stand in a corner. I only have two corners in my bedroom because it’s the smallest room in the house, shaped like a wedge of cheese. The big front bedroom is Mum and Dad’s; the one at the back is my sister Angela’s; the little one over the garage is my brother Tom’s; and the tiny one that is the size of a broom cupboard is mine. Mum says that when Angela goes to university, Tom can have her room, and I can have his. And when Tom goes to university, I can choose any room. But since Angela is only fifteen, I think I will be stuck in my broom cupboard for a long time. I don’t really mind; I quite like my little bedroom. It’s cozy, like a nest. I love the way the roof slopes down and the window is at floor level. The only problem is the lack of corners! My bed is in one corner, and my wardrobe is in the other. 

I tried to fit Gran’s cabinet into the space between the roof and the floor, but it was just a little too tall. Then I thought, if I can’t cut anything off Gran’s cabinet, how about cutting a hole in the carpet? It seemed like the obvious solution. What Dad calls lateral thinking. I thought he would be pleased with me. He always tells us to ‘think outside the box.’ And that was exactly what I was doing!'

Text: 'The novel ‘The Borrowers’ tells the story of a family of tiny people who live secretly in the walls and floors of a house. They “borrow” things from normal-sized people to survive. When I was asked to direct a TV version of the novel, I knew it would be difficult to meet people’s expectations. Fans of the book have strong ideas about how it should be. I used the original drawings from the book a lot because I didn’t want to be criticized for getting it wrong. The author wanted the series to show the story from the Borrowers' point of view, not from the humans', which made filming more complicated. 

The most important thing was to get the size right. The Borrowers are ten times smaller than humans, so when we filmed them walking across a room or going on a borrowing mission, we had to be ten times further away than usual. When filming the human world around the Borrowers, the crew had to crawl on the ground and film from no higher than 15 centimeters to show the Borrowers' perspective. They went through many pairs of jeans! We only raised the cameras for aerial shots. 

One big challenge was to create the right shadows when combining the tiny Borrowers with the normal-sized background. We developed a special technique for this. After the series aired, famous US director George Lucas called to ask how we did it. The only permanent set we built was the Borrowers' home under the floorboards, filled with large objects to make the actors look small. It was very surreal. When I asked them to carry things like a giant pair of scissors, they really got into it. I remember the coins being bigger than dinner plates and hard to lift. We often had to stop filming because the crew laughed so much. 

In the story, there is a scene where the Borrowers are swept down a drain. To film this, actors had to go down a tunnel with hoses, and they said it was so scary that they didn’t need to act. One important thing for me was getting the costumes right, which other directors have struggled with in past versions. I had the costumes made from heavy canvas so they looked like dolls' clothes. This made it hard for the leading actress to move. She couldn’t sit down during breaks and had to be sewn into her dress every morning. The lead actor’s trousers were made from a rug because normal fabric would have looked too smooth. Unfortunately, it was very hot during filming, and I don’t think they appreciated my attention to detail with the costumes! 

Most of the action away from the Borrowers’ home had to be filmed with the actors in front of a blue screen on an empty set. It was hard for them to react to things that weren’t really there. I had to draw pictures of every scene to show how each one should look – I made 2,000 drawings by the end. They weren’t perfect, but they worked well enough. The budget didn’t allow for time in special effects studios during the day, so I spent three months working at night. We had to work quickly – I once filmed a whole scene before realizing there was no film in the camera. But in the end, everything came together, and I think the series was successful in capturing the magic of the books.'

Text: 'Mom stops the car at the corner of my new school, Palm Grove High School. She looks around nervously, searching for journalists that aren’t there. I wonder how long it will take before the chaos starts. It always does. The fake smiles, the people who want to be my friends, and the ones asking for free tickets to my dad’s concerts. “Everything’s going to be fine,” I tell her. She kisses her fingertip and touches my cheek before I get out of the car. Then she drives away, leaving me alone in this new school and situation. But this is what I wanted. I wanted to escape my old life on the road with tour tutors. While the rest of the band is renting here for recording, we are staying for good. I insisted on coming to this school because I want to meet real kids. How about a kid with a mom who works in an office or a dad who mows lawns? That would be so cool. 

I walk into the school’s main office. “Hi, I need my schedule, please,” I tell the school secretary. “Name?” She looks as friendly as an ice bucket. “Desert McGraw.” “Desirée?” she asks, leaning closer. “Desert,” I repeat. The secretary seems confused. “Oh,” she says and types “McGraw” on her keyboard. That’s one good thing. Few people recognize my last name because my dad uses his stage name. “What grade?” “Eleventh.” “One second, it’s printing,” the secretary says. Then she rips the sheet and hands it to me. English Literature, first period. Great, I can handle that. English has always been my favorite subject. I’ll be late, though. English is in Room 214, on the second floor. I studied the map last night so I wouldn’t look silly searching for my classes. 

When I get to the door, I hear the teacher taking attendance. “Aurelio Gonzalez.” “Here.” She continues while I slip in quietly and sit at the last desk in the second row. The girl next to me smiles. She looks at my very normal outfit – jeans and a T-shirt. Ha! Nobody will suspect me now! “Nice shoes,” she whispers. I look down at my expensive shoes with tan flowers. Oh no, I shouldn’t have worn these. “Thanks,” I say. The teacher pauses in the attendance. “Desert... McGraw?” she says carefully. “Here.” The teacher smiles and introduces herself as Ms. Smigla. She talks a lot and eventually gives us our course outlines. After we review them and she tells us about the books we need to read this year, she actually gives us time to socialize! All teachers should understand how important this is. 

“So why did you move here?” my new friend asks. I have a few choices. Do I say it’s because I wanted a normal life away from cameras and reporters? Or the real reason, according to Dad? “We need a change, Desert,” he said, “and this is the perfect place to record the new album. Energy, color, culture... just what our last album needed.” Personally, I think he just wants to relax on the beach. Why else would they choose South Beach Sounds, a recording studio close to the sand? “My dad had to move,” I tell her. Yes, lies work better. “What does he do?” she asks. Oh, whatever. Everyone will find out eventually. But at least I’ll have some time to pretend to be normal until they do. “He’s an artist,” I say, playing with the zipper on my backpack. “Cool. I’m Becca, by the way.” And she doesn’t seem to care. Great.'

Text: 

Today, American teenage girls are expected to do a lot. They should be the president of the Student Council, have a part-time job, volunteer, and do well in school. Being an average teenager is not enough anymore. Many people think that if teenagers do not have big goals, they are being lazy. 

Kristen Loose, a teenager, says, "Adults often forget how much pressure we have. We have a lot of homework, tests, activities, jobs, chores, and we also want to have a social life." Even with all this stress, negative stereotypes about teenagers still exist. Some people think teenagers are lazy, disrespectful, rebellious, loud, reckless, and only care about themselves. While some teenagers may fit these stereotypes, Kristen believes it is unfair to label all teenagers this way. 

Kristen admits she often has her cellphone nearby, but she uses it for important things, not just for fun. Teenagers use their phones to make their lives easier. They are expected to have quick access to information and to be reachable all the time, which can look like an addiction to their phones. With smartphones, tablets, and social media, students can do their homework anywhere. Instead of just listening to music on the way to school, they might listen to language lessons. Schoolwork now requires attention all day and night, which can be tiring for teenagers. 

Many teenagers wake up around 6 a.m. or 7 a.m. and often stay up past midnight. Their days are filled with school, activities, family responsibilities, and homework. They usually get less than the recommended nine hours of sleep each night. A survey by the US National Sleep Foundation found that only about 20 percent of teenagers get enough sleep. Additionally, 28 percent of teens said they fall asleep in school about once a week because they are too tired. 

Lindamarie Olsen, another teenager, thinks she has about 18 hours of free time each week. With 168 hours in a week, 18 hours is not much. She does not spend her free time on social media or watching TV. Instead, she focuses on volunteering. Lindamarie says, "People think teenagers only care about themselves, but I love volunteering. I want to make a positive impact in my school and community." 

In the future, the stereotypes about teenagers may change, but they will continue to challenge these ideas and make a difference in the world. There will always be new generations of students who are making an impact before they even finish school.

The teenage members of the Earth to Sky Calculus Club live in and around Bishop, a mountain town in the US, surrounded by wilderness, east of the Sierra Nevada mountains. In the last few years, this small group has launched over fifty balloons to the edge of space, about 35 km above the Earth. This is a long-term science project that combines astronomy and adventure, which is likely why teenagers want to join. I joined them one weekend in late spring. They were about to release a high-altitude balloon to record shooting stars. Shooting stars happen when a rock or piece of metal from space enters the Earth's atmosphere and creates a bright trail of light.

As it got dark, the teenagers attached a soft insulated $5 lunch box to the bottom of the balloon. Inside the lunch box were a camera, a device to measure altitude, and a thermometer to check the temperature as the balloon rose. Two GPS trackers were placed on the outside of the lunch box to help the group find it later. They used a gas tank, donated by a supporter from a nearby state, to inflate the balloon, which slowly grew to the size of a small car. An older boy made a seven-hour round trip to get the gas tank. “I didn’t really mind,” he said. For kids in this club, that’s normal.

Finally, it was time for lift-off. “Five, four, three, two, one,” they counted down, and the balloon began to rise. Some of them ran and followed its path with powerful flashlights until they could no longer see it in the dark sky. There was a quiet moment filled with wonder. Then the balloon disappeared into the night. After the launch, most students went home, but a few stayed to watch the shooting stars. They lay on blankets on the mountainside and looked at a sky so clear that it was hard to believe they were only four hours from Los Angeles, a busy city with around 4 million people. I saw a boy climb into a sleeping bag and quickly fall asleep. “We’re the only ones talking,” said one girl quietly. “I know,” whispered another. A meteor shot across the sky.

As the balloon rose, the air pressure decreased, and the balloon expanded until it was almost the size of a house. Then it popped with a loud noise. A parachute helped the lunch box land safely back on Earth. The students would find it the next day using the GPS trackers. Getting it back was not easy, but that was part of the fun. There is little inhabited land around Bishop, so the lunch box usually lands in a remote area. “Recoveries are a big part of the program,” said the group’s leader, noting they have lost only two lunch boxes in 53 launches. “Part of the journey is getting to know this landscape in a way you normally wouldn’t.”

On this occasion, the lunch box landed 84 km west of Bishop, but the recovery team had to drive south of the Sierra and then back up the western side of the mountains. They had to decide whether to drive or walk, as it could be dangerous if the lunch box was on a high peak or in a tall tree. “These students are familiar with the Eastern Sierra,” their leader said. “What seems wild and dangerous to some is just a way of life for others.” In the end, it took them 11 hours to find the lunch box. It was in a canyon, on a flat rock, near a waterfall. The camera did not record any shooting stars. While this was a bit disappointing, it was also a chance to discuss the effects of atmospheric waves and how they might work above mountains. And it was one more adventure story to share with anyone who asked.

Text: Chloe Morgan admits that science, especially Palaeontology, did not interest her much until she was fifteen. It happened by chance when her younger brother was excited about dinosaurs, a phase many children go through. She had not experienced this interest herself and often dismissed it. However, when she helped him with a science project and read an article about recent discoveries, she was amazed and realized she wanted to pursue this field.

Chloe recalls meeting her first professional palaeontologist, Matt Cornelius, who was already well-known despite being young. She was nervous at first, worried he might think she was just an annoying kid with questions. However, she felt more comfortable when he showed patience and listened to her.

I ask Chloe about how palaeontologists are shown in movies and TV shows. She thinks that films like Jurassic Park, which use special effects to create dinosaurs, have increased public interest in these creatures, but not necessarily in Palaeontology itself. She finds it frustrating that palaeontologists are often portrayed as either strange geniuses or socially awkward people. She believes these portrayals do not reflect the reality of their work.

Chloe explains that her job is very varied. She spends time digging up dinosaur bones, working in laboratories to analyze fossils, and writing for scientific publications. Although it is not always part of her job, she also tries to communicate scientific findings to the public. She believes it is important to help young people understand science, as talking about dinosaurs can inspire them to learn more about the natural world and other scientific topics.

The recent TV documentary Walking with Dinosaurs gave Chloe a chance to influence how dinosaurs are shown on screen. She notes that the creators of the program were knowledgeable, and she only needed to provide advice occasionally. Most of her work involved ensuring that the dinosaurs shown lived during the same time period. The program attracted viewers of all ages because it presented dinosaurs in a way that was very different from movies like Jurassic Park, making them appear more realistic.

Chloe thinks dinosaurs continue to fascinate us because they connect to our natural curiosity and desire to explore. They remind us that there is still much to discover in the world, and Palaeontology allows us to travel back in time.

Text: "I will say this once: when you are traveling by car with your family, even if you are six years old, you know that you are not ‘there yet,’ even when you keep asking ‘Are we there yet?’ The truth is, once you arrive, it’s not ‘there’ anymore; it’s ‘here.’ So if you think you might be ‘there’ already, you should ask ‘Are we here yet?’ I’m sure no one wishes to be ‘there yet’ more than the parents who hear that question over and over on long car trips. 

Think about it. Wouldn’t you rather relax in the back seat, with no responsibilities? You can watch DVDs, listen to music, or do puzzles you haven’t finished, while the beautiful scenery passes by outside the window. In the front seat, there’s mum or dad, who gives out juice boxes and cookies, changes the radio station, and keeps everything running smoothly. 

But then, someone in the car does something annoying – usually my younger brother, Tim. He might put his foot on my side of the seat. I can’t let that happen, so I put my foot on his side. Soon, he’s all over my space, and a fight starts. The driver and co-pilot have to reach back and separate us while the car swerves. They tell Tim to stay in his own seat and keep his hands to himself. This calms things down for a bit, and we can enjoy the beautiful views again.

Later, I try to read, but I feel a draft on my arm. The window isn’t open, so where is it coming from? Tim is next to me, breathing on me. He’s not touching me, so he thinks he’s being clever. This makes me angry. Tim gets yelled at again, and the car swerves more. Eventually, things calm down again.

Over the years, Dad has come up with ways to handle us in the back seat. When we ask ‘Are we there yet?’ he often says, ‘Yes, we’re here. Get out of the car.’ But we are still on the highway, going 70 miles an hour. Then he says, ‘Oh, maybe we’re not there yet.’ This keeps us quiet for a while. 

You can tell when you finally arrive because the adults jump out of the car and move as far away from us as possible after all those hours. So remember: if mum and dad are still close enough to answer your question, then the answer is: no. You’re not there yet."
