John and Zuzi Morgan have opened a café in Oxford, UK, where people can enjoy coffee and cake while playing board games. They hope that customers will love the experience and want to come back. Zuzi explains that they wanted to create a space where people can connect without staring at screens. She believes that people naturally want to be together and talk to each other.

The games played in their café are called ‘Eurogames’. These games often have gentle themes, like farming and building landscapes. The first Eurogame was The Settlers of Catan, created by German designer Klaus Teuber. In this game, players build settlements on an island and trade resources with each other, keeping everyone engaged until the end. This idea was improved in ‘co-operative’ games, where all players work together to win or lose as a team, which encourages more social interaction. One popular co-operative game is Pandemic, created by North American designer Matt Leacock. In Pandemic, players work together to solve global problems. Leacock was inspired by a Eurogame called Lord of the Rings, which is based on the book of the same name. He remembers feeling scared and excited while playing it with friends, and he wanted to create a game that gave players a similar experience.

Leacock has loved board games since he was a child, but he often felt disappointed when games did not meet his expectations. With help from his uncle, he started redesigning games to make them better. Pandemic became very successful, and its follow-up game included a lot of storytelling. Leacock explains that it is similar to video games because players develop characters, learn new rules, and the story changes as they play.

The growth of the video game industry has helped the popularity of modern board games. Many people now play games on their smartphones, making them more open to playing board games. Ben Hogg, who works for a game company, says that everyone is a mobile gamer now. 

For a while, video games allowed some social interaction, like playing together in arcades or on the couch. However, as multiplayer games moved online, players became more distant from each other. This led some people to seek out board games to play with others in person. In John and Zuzi's busy café, tabletop gaming has become more than just fun. In our online world, games are now something to share directly with others, and this trend is likely to continue.

**Simplified Text:**

Jamie Scott has written and produced some of the biggest hits in the UK in recent years. His story shows that endurance and persistence are very important in the music business, even if your career starts with many failures. He says his mother was ‘an amazing singer’ who helped him learn to play the guitar. The only radio he listened to at home was a local station for older people, which explains some of his early influences. He was 12 years old when he first heard a modern song. Around the same time, he had to choose between playing tennis, which he did at a national level, and music. He spent his lunchtimes in the music room at school learning songs on the piano. He said, ‘I was doing well in tennis, but it was not what I wanted to do for my whole life. It was just too much hard work.’

At 17, he left school to try to become a performer. He formed a duo with a friend who was a good guitarist but did not share his passion for performing. Jamie remembers going to his parents and telling them he wanted to pursue music. He had been writing lyrics during economics lessons and playing the piano every day while others were outside playing. His dad gave him 18 months to succeed; if he didn’t, he would have to find a job. After some close calls with record labels, he was signed to a music publisher at 19 because of one song. However, record labels wanted him to be a solo artist, so he had to part ways with his friend.

Eventually, he found success behind the scenes rather than on stage. After a tough time with a record label in the UK, he asked to leave and joined another label to release a new album. However, fame and fortune did not come easily. He said, ‘I feel like I’ve been in the wrong place at the wrong time for most of my career, but as a writer, I’ve been in the right place at the right time.’ Writing for other artists is where he really found success. He believes he is one of the main writers in the UK that labels turn to for new artists. He helps launch their careers.

Sometimes, he has to explain to the artists he works with that wanting to write popular songs is not something to be ashamed of. He asks them, ‘Why don’t you want to? Don’t you want 10 million people streaming your music next month?’ He believes they should aim to create something amazing that will also sell well. It is refreshing to hear someone in pop music speak openly about wanting to write big hits. Jamie is not arrogant; he simply knows he wants to write number one songs and has the talent to do it. Instead of worrying about what others think, he focuses on his work. He says, ‘When I go into the studio with someone, we need to aim for the best music of next year. It’s not just about what’s cool. We want to write classic modern pop songs.’

Tony Connor is a new kind of celebrity. He is very popular online, but many people, like me, may not know him because we don’t watch videos of people doing tricks on bikes. He is a "street trials cyclist." This means he jumps from difficult places, like roofs or walls, to land safely in other hard spots. These jumps are filmed and shared online.

On the day I interview him, we meet in a BMX park on a Saturday morning. The local kids know who he is, and some older people come to tell him he’s “an absolute legend.” After watching him perform, I agree with them. At first, I was unsure about him, but I am impressed by his bravery and creativity. Before each jump, he explains what he plans to do, and sometimes I can’t believe he will succeed. When I compliment him, he seems uninterested and a bit sad. Even though he is famous online, Tony says he does not like being a celebrity. He says, “I find the social side of it difficult. I see the value of being in touch with fans, but I prefer to actually do things instead of just talking about them.” This is interesting because his fame comes from social media and the small cameras that help create this content. He says, “This technology allows people like me to earn money.” Sometimes he feels like everyone is filming themselves or looking at screens, and he doesn’t always agree with that.

However, he is not complaining. Through his videos, he makes a good living from what used to be just a hobby. After many years of interviewing top athletes, I have learned that two important things help a child become a great competitor: energy and the ability to handle disappointment. These qualities can be more important than talent and help someone keep going even after failure. The riskier the sport, the more mental strength is needed. Even in the park, Tony fell a few times on what he thought were easy but new challenges. He just got back up and kept trying until he succeeded.

Not everyone sees Tony as a hero. Some people think he is reckless and takes too many risks. He says, “People who say this may care, but they don’t understand. They probably have never ridden a trials bike and don’t know much about the sport. They don’t realize I get advice from experts to reduce the risks.” In reality, Tony is careful about the risks he takes. He explains, “People are different. Some never feel scared, and they shouldn’t do these sports. It’s smart to know the dangers. The rest of us can be divided into those who can overcome fear and those who cannot. I am in the group that feels fear but finds a way to move past it. I’m not addicted to risk; I spend a lot of time planning and preparing. Sometimes I ride around for a while to get ready before trying a new jump. I know I must stay calm just before I jump. If I fully commit, then I’m fine.”

Text: 'Television presenter Helen Skelton has taken on many dangerous challenges for charity, such as running a marathon in the desert and traveling down the Amazon river in a small boat. For her latest challenge, Helen walked on a high wire, which is a long thin piece of metal, 66 meters above the ground, between two towers of an empty power station. There was no safety net, just a belt around her waist connected to another wire above. To help her balance and avoid falling, she carried a long stick that weighed eight kilograms. Helen trained with an expert high-wire walker. Even though she had some circus skills, she found out that high-wire walking was very different. ‘The training was a shock,’ said Helen. ‘I didn’t know how strong I needed to be. Every day started at 8 am with a run up a steep hill, followed by an hour of exercises, and then another hour practicing on the wire. I also had to learn how to fall onto the wire so that if I slipped, I could keep going. Every time I fell on the wire, it hurt a lot. But it was important to stay positive: if I was nervous and started shaking, the wire would shake too!’ On the day of the challenge, it was windy, and Helen calmed herself by taking deep breaths as she moved step by step along the wire. The 150-meter walk took 15 minutes. ‘That was the scariest thing I’ve done,’ she said afterwards. ‘I’m glad it’s over!’ However, this experience has not stopped Helen from planning her next charity project: to reach the South Pole by ski, kite, and bike.'

In 2006, Jeff Somers started a journey around the world on a penny farthing, an old-style bicycle with one large wheel and one small wheel. He had already written a book about his travels in Canada using a 50-year-old car. He loved motorsport and worked building racing car engines. To save money, Jeff rode an old bicycle to work and also used it for a holiday in Amsterdam. He said, “That trip opened my eyes. I decided to see the world by bike.” Jeff did not want a regular touring bike and wanted to build one himself. He thought the most unusual bike would be a penny farthing, so he visited a museum to learn how they were made. After two attempts in 2001 and 2003, when he had to stop because of a knee injury, he finally began his journey in 2006. He traveled for three years, visiting 23 countries on four continents. The best part of the trip was reaching Tibet and seeing Mount Everest. He met cyclists who could ride up mountains, but he never regretted using his penny farthing. The further he traveled from home, the more surprised people were by it. His worst experience was having to drink dirty water from a stream, which made him very sick. He spent ten days in a hostel without medicine. He had no money for a hospital or to return home. Despite everything, Jeff now says, “If I could afford it, I would start traveling again tomorrow on my penny farthing.”

Text: "I work at a university in the US with my team, and we are trying to learn more about water birds, especially the American black duck. We have just started using a new tool called a ‘night-vision scope’, which helps us see the ducks in the dark! We are concerned about black ducks because their numbers have decreased a lot, and we are not sure if there is enough food for them on the east coast. We have a lot of information about what they do during the day, but we know very little about their nighttime activities because we did not have the right equipment. This new scope will give us clear images, even on nights without a moon, so we can learn more and make better decisions about protecting their habitat. 

It is hard work. There are four of us, and we each work six hours a day. We have studied ducks in different places, and I have had to take a boat to some locations and write down notes on every duck I see. The weather has not been helpful – some nights are warm, but most of the time it is rainy. It is so quiet that I have needed a lot of coffee to stay awake! We have only missed one working day because the snow was too deep for our special vehicles. Still, I enjoy the challenge, especially compared to the summer when we will spend hours in a laboratory looking at our results together. It will be hard to be inside, but it is important to do this work. I wouldn’t change it for anything!"

Text: "When I tell people what I do for a living, they can hardly believe this job exists. But I’m not joking! I spend my days at work eating chocolate! Tasting chocolate is an important part of making sure that customers get perfect, high-quality chocolate from the company I work for. Every week, I receive samples, which are small amounts of chocolate from our factory, and I have to check them for taste, texture, and smell. I also taste the raw materials we usually use, like nuts and fruit. I spend time choosing the best ones to put into the chocolate. Next to my company office, I have a kitchen where I can test and taste the products I make, and I keep my colleagues happy by giving them samples! My kitchen is full of machines and ingredients to work with. It’s great to have a private space I can go to during the day. No two days are the same in this job. Sometimes I am at our food lab, and other times I’m out of the country buying our raw materials, which can be difficult because I have a young family. But I love the variety and lack of routine in my job, even though I think the chocolate itself is the best part! The question I get asked the most is whether I get bored of chocolate. I’ve worked with it for a long time, and I’ve never felt like I didn’t want to eat it. In fact, I often go home and eat some more in the evening!"

Text: 'Have you ever thought about what it’s like to perform in a circus? Sophia Grayson works at Circus Experience, a center that teaches young people circus skills. She says her course is popular because it includes many skills, such as juggling, throwing and catching balls, and even fire, as well as trapeze, where performers fly through the air in front of an amazed audience. 

In the year-long course, students gradually take more risks in each class, and parents can come to some classes to see their progress. Sophia explains, “For a circus career, performers need to avoid doing the same thing all the time – it’s important to keep performances exciting and full of action. If you want to be successful in the circus, you must keep practicing. Another great part of this job is making friends with other performers and learning from them. Staying fit is also very important – circus artists, like athletes, train every day to stay strong. Training is essential, but the best performers are those who want to succeed, have creativity, and never stop improving their skills. 

People often think that circus performers are likely to get injured or that they only work for a short time each year. However, the real challenge is planning for the future because you can only travel while you’re young, and then you need to think about other options.” The course also teaches business planning. Many former students have started their own businesses around the world and are happy to share their experiences. Sophia warns, though, that it’s not a job for making a lot of money! “The work usually does not provide a regular salary. It’s also competitive – but a lot of fun!”'

Text: 'You may not know her name or face, but you have probably heard her many times. Mariam Hobson is a professional backing singer. This means she sings in the background to support the main singer. Many people think that backing singers are not good enough to be lead singers, but that is not true – they often have to be even better. People like Mariam are the real stars of the music industry! 

“What I love about my job is that when I walk into the recording studio, I never know what I will be asked to sing,” she says. “It could be classical, jazz, hip-hop, or rock. Sometimes, it might be a funny little song for a radio station or an advertisement. I am often surprised by what the producers ask for. Once, I was asked to sing like a fish underwater! But I never argue; I just do my job!”

“Excellent musical skills are very important for my work, and I need to learn quickly. There is often no written music to follow. I will never forget my first time recording background music for a film. It was very complicated because there were eight of us, each singing a different part, along with an orchestra. I was scared because if I made a mistake, we would have to record everything again, which nobody likes. Recording sessions are long enough as it is.”

“One of my favorite jobs is recording for songwriters. Less experienced writers do not always know which musical range is best for a female voice. By listening to me sing their song, they can figure out how to improve it.”

Text: 'Julie Deane started with only basic knowledge of fashion, but she built a successful business selling ‘satchels’ – traditional bags used by schoolchildren. These satchels are now sold in famous shops and are popular with many celebrities. Before deciding to sell satchels, Julie made a list of different business ideas, like cake decorating and party planning, and thought carefully about her options. When she chose satchels, not everyone agreed with her. Julie said, “Many people said there was no demand for them – but I was sure.” She involved her family from the beginning, working with her mother, who had never had a job but had a natural talent for business. The design of the satchels was inspired by children’s storybooks. Although Julie didn’t know much about fashion blogs, they became important for her success. At first, she sold about one satchel a week. To create interest, Julie sent satchels to fashion writers, hoping they would write about them in their blogs. They did, and interest in her satchels grew, along with the speed at which her company produced them. Julie now enjoys waiting to see which celebrity will be seen with a satchel! While other companies spend money on online ads, she uses the internet community for ideas for new styles, keeping her products fresh and exciting. There was a difficult time when another company copied Julie’s design to sell similar bags. Because of this, she now makes sure she trusts her production team as much as her own staff. Visitors often comment on the positive atmosphere in her offices – people enjoy working there. There is now a new factory, and while the buildings are important, it is the team that makes it a special place.'

Text: 'When Vicky Harmiston was a child, her parents allowed her and her brother Jamie to choose how they spent their free time. Vicky decided to try many different sports. She was a good swimmer, and her coach at the swimming club believed she could become a champion. However, the club was far from her home, making it hard for her to balance training with her schoolwork. As teenagers, Jamie, who loved cycling, bought a special racing bike and began competing. Vicky thought this looked exciting and wanted to try it too. She says it was the best decision she ever made. Soon, she was cycling every day and doing very well. The track was close to her school, so it was easy for her to attend training sessions after school. Vicky had a successful career in track cycling and won several competitions. When she was 28, she retired from competitive cycling. Vicky said, ‘For years I loved winning, but I started to feel tired of it all – when the excitement goes, there’s no point. Luckily, I found a new career.’ Vicky got a job with a charity called CycleZone. ‘We work with young people who have never enjoyed sports,’ she explains. ‘The first thing we do is teach them to ride a bike. We want them to believe in themselves and their abilities. CycleZone does a great job, bringing young people together so they feel part of a larger group.’ The charity uses celebrities to promote their work. Vicky says, ‘I know some people think the support of a celebrity is not always good for a charity. They believe celebrities do it for their own benefit, which can hide the real work of the charity. But if famous singers and actors can help, I think they should.’

Text: 'Singer-songwriter Ana Ronson grew up in Ireland. Even though her parents were not musicians, there was always music in their home. Her grandfather played the guitar and taught Ana and her brother how to play. The first time Ana sang in front of an audience was at school. She was so nervous that her teacher had to help her off the stage. This teacher suggested that joining the school theatre club might help her feel more confident. After being in the club for a while, she happily sang with 50 other students at a concert at the end of the term. A year later, her brother, who was in a band, asked her to write a song for them. She wrote her first song, Falling Stars, in just three days and enjoyed it so much that she signed up for a songwriting course with a professional songwriter. Even though she was the youngest student, she knew more about music than many of the others. However, Ana felt that the teacher did not listen to her, and she wrote a song called Something to Say about how this made her feel. She shared this song online, and it became very popular. She was happy when people left comments saying they loved it and found new meanings in the lyrics each time they listened. Joss Alton, the owner of a recording company called Isotope Music, flew from the other side of Ireland to ask her to join his company. At first, she was unsure because she did not know anything about Isotope and did not want anyone telling her what to sing. However, Joss convinced her that this would not happen, and soon after, she performed at a concert in Dublin organized by Isotope. They sold all the tickets quickly, and it was an amazing night. Ana says she is less interested in writing songs about happy times; when life is difficult, she has more to express. One of her favorite songs is Decision, which is about why her brother stopped singing for a while and how unhappy it made him. While she hopes her fans will enjoy her songs, her goal is to write about personal experiences that are important to her.'

Text: 'Last year, I went on an amazing trip – a guided boat tour along the west coast of Canada. It was my brother Harry’s idea. He is a journalist, like me, and he wanted to write articles about the trip. He loves boats, but I don’t share that interest. However, I had always wanted to visit this area since I saw it on TV as a child, especially because our great-grandparents lived there before moving to Europe. I kept asking Harry if I could join him until he finally agreed! A few days before we left, there were storms in the area we were going to. Luckily, the weather forecast for our trip was good. I was busy at work and didn’t have much time to prepare, but Harry promised he would take care of everything, so I stopped worrying. 

After arriving in Canada, we joined the group, packed our supplies into small boats, and set off. The guide said that very few people live along that coast, and indeed, the only other living creatures we saw that first morning were dolphins and birds. We could see islands in the distance, but the early-morning fog made it hard to see far, so I focused on the beautiful patterns our boat made in the water. We often stopped for hours to explore the rock pools on the beaches. They were full of colorful fish, many of which I didn’t recognize. It was nice to forget about how fast or slow the day was going. We never forgot lunch or dinner, which we all cooked together over campfires. When we finally fell asleep on the boats each evening, even though the beds were hard, it felt like a stress-free life! When it was time to leave, I felt sad. How could I go back to normal life? But I knew if I stayed, I would miss my family and friends. I was also excited to tell everyone at home about our adventures!'

Text: "My dad was a professional basketball player in Germany, just like his father before him. When I was a kid, I went to many of his games. You might think that watching so many matches would make me love basketball, but it actually did the opposite. I enjoyed telling my friends how good my dad was, especially when he won, but I usually took a book to read instead of watching the games.

When I started secondary school, I was still two years away from being a teenager, but I was already two meters tall. Because of my height, my sports teacher asked if I wanted to train with the basketball team. I liked the training, but I thought I needed to improve my skills before playing in a real match. However, the teacher believed in me more than I believed in myself. After some time, I agreed, and a few weeks later, I played against a team from another school. My parents came to watch, which made me more nervous, but it turned out fine!

For the next four years, I practiced every day and did really well. I even joined an adult team before moving to a special sports academy in the USA when I was fifteen. The coach there trains Olympic basketball players, and it was amazing to work with him. However, I didn’t enjoy living far from my parents at first. At home, I hadn’t spent much time with my friends because of all the training, so that part wasn’t a big change for me. Eventually, I got used to my new life, and my English improved quickly too!

I became a professional player at eighteen, three years after arriving in the USA. I had been taller than most players in the professional league since I was fifteen, but I needed to gain weight to match my height. My coach knew a team that would take me while I was still in college, so I joined them and have never regretted it."

Text: "Seven years ago, I was studying Tourism at college, but I needed a part-time job because my course was expensive. After thinking about different options, I trained to be a weekend tour guide in my home city, Chicago, USA. This meant taking visitors around the city, and I was surprised by how much I enjoyed giving those tours. I got to see the city I had lived in my whole life from the perspective of tourists, and it felt like a new experience every time! After finishing my studies, I decided to become a full-time tour guide. I thought it would be easy, but when I researched what I needed to do, I found out that to get a license as a full-time tour guide, I had to know much more than I had learned so far. All Chicago guides must be able to answer many questions about the city, including local architecture, history, and public transport rules. After several challenging but interesting months, I earned my tour guide qualification and registered as an independent tour guide. 

Tour guiding is not just about knowing historical facts or keeping track of your group in crowds. There are many other important skills. You should be entertaining and tell interesting stories, and most importantly, you need to react to changing situations. For example, if a place you thought was open is actually closed when you arrive, or if a route changes. Tourists do not want to hear about problems or that they are missing something; they just want to enjoy a well-organized tour. I need to make sure visitors are happy with my tours; otherwise, they might leave a negative review online. Like most tour guides, I know that these reviews are very important because good reviews attract more customers. That is why making tours fun and stress-free is essential. For me, the enthusiasm and energy I put into my job mean that my reviews are usually very good, and my tours are often recommended to other visitors coming to Chicago."

Text: 'My name is Ella, and I am 22 years old. Last year, I went to Thailand for two weeks with my sister, Josie. Even though she is five years younger than me, we have a good relationship. We went to help as volunteers at an elephant sanctuary, which is a place where people care for sick and rescued elephants. At first, I was unsure if we would have much in common with the other volunteers because they were all older than us. We were also nervous because it was our first time doing something like this. In the end, we had nothing to worry about. One of our main jobs at the sanctuary was to collect food for the elephants. Elephants eat a lot of grass and banana plants, so this took most of the day. Josie found it very hard work, but seeing the elephants enjoy their food made it worth it for me. We also helped wash the elephants in the river with big brushes and soap. I found that very fun, even though I got wetter than the elephants! The part of the day I looked forward to the most was the evening. By the light of the moon, we led the elephants into the forest where they spent the night. All the volunteers stayed in the same house. Josie and I shared a bedroom, so we didn’t have much space. We chose to do this because Josie didn’t want to be alone. It was hot and humid, especially at night, but we expected that. The meals were delicious and did not include meat, which neither of us likes. After dinner, all the volunteers and staff spent the evenings talking and playing games. Now that we are back in the UK, Josie doesn’t often talk about Thailand. But if someone asks her if she enjoyed her time at the sanctuary, she says she loved it. However, I think she might be a little annoyed with herself for not enjoying her time there fully because she missed her friends too much. But when she thinks back, she can see how lucky she was to go there. Maybe she will go back one day – I definitely will!'

Text: "My name is Gina D’Costa, and I own a flower shop in the UK. We sell flowers not just to people for their homes or as gifts; we have many different customers. Hotels and offices often use flowers in their reception areas, and sometimes we provide flowers for businesses to use in their advertising photos. Once, I even decorated a castle with flowers for a wedding. It was a lot of work, but I was very proud of what we accomplished. 

My day starts at 4 a.m. when I go to the market to buy fresh flowers. Most people are still asleep at that time, and my friends think I’m a bit crazy, but I love what I do. It can be cold and dark, but I don’t let that bother me. The flower market is amazing, with flowers from all over the world. The sights and smells make it hard to choose. If I were buying for myself, I would probably choose only pink flowers because it’s my favorite color. But I have to remember that what I like may not be what my customers want. 

Sometimes, I can’t find the flowers that customers want because not all flowers are available all year. I don’t enjoy arguing about prices with the flower sellers, but it’s part of the job. Flowers can be expensive, so I try to get the best price I can. 

Back at the shop, we look at customer orders and prepare vases with the flowers I bought. Then we create flower arrangements and calculate the costs. Customers are often surprised by how much they cost, and I sometimes have to ask them to reconsider their choices. Some people might think this is too much trouble, but I enjoy finding the best flowers for the budget someone has. That’s what you have to do when you’re selling things – I wouldn’t want any other job!"

Text: "My city has a modern cinema that shows all the latest films and many films for kids on weekends. It is close to my home, but a year ago, I realized something was missing – the chance to discuss a film in detail with others after watching it. So, I started a film club with two friends! We decided not to rent a cinema for our films. Instead, we choose a different place in the city each month. For example, we used an old factory to show a film set in Antarctica. It was very cold, which made the atmosphere perfect for the film, and it was amazing! Some places we use are free because the owners sell snacks during the film, so we can keep our prices low. We are happy to cover our costs – we don’t want to make a profit. Each time we show a film, it gets easier for us, especially now that we have our own reliable equipment. We can also see how many tickets we’ve sold online, so we don’t worry about empty seats! There is always a lot to do, but when people of all ages tell us at the end how much they enjoyed it, it feels great. Our website has helped us connect with other film clubs across the country. We have visited them to see how they do things, but it’s always nice to return to our own club! We started a blog because we know most people look online for film information instead of reading local papers. We also put up a few posters in cafés. However, nothing is as effective as word of mouth – people telling their friends about us. The audience loves the special activities we organize with each film – last month, we had a movie quiz that everyone enjoyed."

Text: "Taking photographs was always my favorite activity as a child. When I was 15, I wanted to take my hobby to the next level, so I decided to start a special project: I would take one photograph every day for a whole year. Many other young photographers had done this before, but it seemed like a great idea to me, so I began. After a few weeks, I decided to share my photos on a website for young photographers. I wanted to create a photo diary and show my work to others. I was surprised to find that many people liked my way of seeing and photographing things. I also enjoyed taking pictures of many different subjects. Then someone suggested that if my photos had a common theme, my project would be even better, and I agreed. So I started to focus more on nature scenes, especially birds and the sky. Many of my photos were black and white, which was different from what many other young photographers were doing, as they were taking color photos. Because of this, I sometimes doubted my project and almost gave up. In the end, I trusted my feelings and became more confident in my style and choices. One day, I showed my project to my art teacher. She told me about a national photography competition for people my age, so I entered some of my photos just for fun. I will never forget the moment when the judges told me I had won first prize; I was so happy because my project meant a lot to me. It was the first time I realized that my photography might be good, and that I could work as a professional photographer. Now, I have my own photography studio, and I have never regretted my career choice."

Text: "I joined the National Youth Challenge (NYC) last year because I wanted to try new activities like camping, sailing, and public speaking. In the NYC, you can do different activities to challenge yourself and learn new things. There are levels from beginner to advanced, led by adult volunteers called ‘leaders’. When you finish each level, you receive a certificate. 

When I first joined, my leader suggested that I help organize activities at a local children’s club for two hours a week. I was unsure about this because I had joined that same club when I was eight and found it hard to make friends. I was shy, and the other children already had their own friends, so I stopped going after a few weeks. However, I decided to take the challenge because I wanted my first NYC certificate. 

Soon, I wanted to spend all my free time at the children’s club. It became much more important to me than just getting the certificate. After I finished the challenge, the NYC leader allowed me to keep volunteering at the club because I had built good relationships with the children. Now, I go there for about four hours a week, and I always look forward to it. 

Because of what I learned at the children’s club, I decided that when I finish school in three years, I want to go to college to become a qualified youth worker, someone who works with children. I had never thought about my future job or youth work before starting at the club. This has been my favorite part of the NYC, and I have improved my communication skills while helping others. I now have several NYC certificates, and one of them is for camping!"

Text: "I was born in Denver, USA, and I started snowboarding when I was eight years old. My dad took me to a resort in the mountains, about two hours from Denver. The hill looked very steep, so my dad had to convince me to try snowboarding. I was too young to ask him if I could start, but he loved snowboarding and wanted me to enjoy it too. He made it look easy, and in the end, I did well. After that, I quickly fell in love with the sport and got better at it. I began competing when I was ten. Some people enter many competitions and get bored, but my love for competing and winning has grown as I’ve gotten older, which helps me push myself more. I like not having a strict plan, and sometimes this works out well, like when I became the first female to get a perfect score of 100 at a local competition. I wasn’t sure I would try the jumps that got me this score until I actually started. That achievement made me trust my abilities more. 

In the summer, I focus on training and my studies when there’s no snow. I train every day, but it’s nice not to follow a strict diet like I do in winter. I also spend a lot of time with my friends then. It helps me deal with not being able to do what I love and what I’m good at. I have to think about my future. Snowboarding is a big part of my life now, but I also think it’s important to have another option in case I don’t become a professional snowboarder or if I get injured. I’m considering whether becoming a doctor is possible if my active life allows time for college. I can’t imagine getting tired of snowboarding, but I know I can’t do it forever."

Text: "When I was fifteen, I wanted everything my friends had, and I never thought about the future. For example, I didn’t know what I wanted to do after school. One day, my best friend got a new phone for her birthday, and I thought I should have one too. My parents said I could only get it if I paid for it myself, so I decided to work part-time and save money. I am grateful to my parents for making me do that because it taught me an important lesson. I worked every Saturday in a café, but I didn’t enjoy it much, so my parents suggested I start my own small business. I had seen my mum making necklaces, so I asked if I could try that. I never thought I would find it so easy, as it looked complicated when I watched my mum. My friends thought it sounded boring, but I was excited about it. My mum showed me that I could create something nice at home with simple tools and materials. I sold my first pieces of jewellery to my friends and family as soon as I finished making them. They said they loved them, but I thought they were just being nice. Even though I was happy they bought them, I still needed to know if they looked good enough for other people. The only way to find out was to rent a market stall with my mum. There are many tourists where I live, and they bought a lot of my items to take home. Soon, we started getting calls from all over the country from people wanting to buy more. They thought we were a big company with many workers, but we were just two people at a market stall! That was when I realized it could work, and it was time to take the next step – creating a website. Since then, I’ve made a lot of money through my business, mostly online, but we still have our stall too. It has been a lot of fun so far."

Text: 'When Janine Stuart was just 13 years old, she wrote a novel called Being Amelia, which became a bestseller. Being Amelia is partly based on Janine’s own life. In an interview about her book, Janine said, “Because of my father’s job, my family moved around the country a lot, so I’ve become good at making new friends. I know what it’s like to be the only new student in a class, and that helped me write about how the main character, Amelia, fits in at a new school. Some of the funniest parts of the book are about Amelia’s home life, especially her relationship with her older brother. Since I’m my parents’ only child, I had to use my imagination to describe that.” 

Janine started her novel one summer when she was bored at home. Her mother had always wanted to be a published author, and her teachers encouraged her to write, so it felt natural for Janine to write. The year before, she entered a short story competition on a young writers’ website and won first prize. That’s why, when Janine finished Being Amelia and sent it to a publishing company, they were eager to read it. They loved it, and a year later, Janine’s novel was in bookshops. 

One review of Being Amelia mentions that, even though the book has pictures of happy teenagers on the cover, the characters face some difficult challenges, which makes them believable. The reviewer says that even though Janine is still very young and Being Amelia isn’t a long novel, she has shown that she is a better writer than many other bestselling authors. Janine is still getting used to being a famous writer: “At first, I hid when people recognized me in the street, but now it’s OK. I want to give advice to other young writers, but they have to find what works for them. For me, I know that if I spend time with my friends, I’ll soon have something interesting to write about!”'

Text: "My name is Tom, and I am fifteen years old. Three years ago, my family and I moved into a castle on a small island. This happened because my father was invited to be the manager of the castle. He works for a group that takes care of historical buildings and keeps them open for visitors. He was happy about this opportunity, but it took some time for the rest of us to agree that he should take the job. We were worried about what life on the island would be like. We knew the castle might not be as comfortable as our warm home across the water, and there was no school there. However, once we moved, we quickly got used to living on the island. The castle is not very beautiful, but our apartment in it is comfortable. In the summer, the island feels friendly because many visitors come, and there are often beach parties. In winter, we mostly see the other families who live on the island, and there are not many teenagers among them, which I had hoped for. The adults help each other and work together on repairs around the island, which can be hard work. 

The biggest change for me was taking a boat every day to my old school. I looked forward to going on stormy days when there are big waves, but the ferries do not run then! I also found out that if I miss the bus to the harbor after school, I miss the last ferry home, which is stressful. So when my friends come to visit, I always tell them to hurry! But we often see amazing views, especially when the sun sets over the sea. Some days, it is so foggy that you cannot see anything, but then a few hours later, it can be bright and sunny again. This still feels incredible, even after living here for a while. Of course, we do have terrible storms, and I sometimes wonder if the castle is strong enough to stay safe. But then I remember it has been here for hundreds of years, and it is still standing!"

Text: 'I live in a house in the beautiful countryside of Scotland. I have always loved nature and wild animals, and six years ago, I started a new hobby – birdwatching! I went to some mountains in northern Scotland with my family, where we saw many birds in their natural environment. I spent hours watching them with my parents, who taught me how to tell different bird species apart and where to find the best places to see them. It was amazing, and after returning home, I joined a local birdwatchers’ club for young people. My goal is to see 200 different bird species, and I am almost there. On family holidays abroad, I have seen birds from other countries, too. We always look for places with birdwatching activities, so I can add new birds to my list! I have been to Egypt, and last summer we went to South America, where I thought I would see my 200th species. I wasn’t too disappointed when it didn’t happen, though, because I have learned that you need to be patient with this hobby. I posted a video online about this challenge, and many teenagers liked it and said it looked like a fascinating hobby. When my teachers saw it, they asked me to give a presentation about birdwatching at school. I didn’t feel nervous until just before I walked onto the stage. I knew I would remember what to say and had some notes to help me, but the whole school and all my friends were watching! I only relaxed when it was over, and the teachers said I had prepared well and they really enjoyed it. I might even do another presentation next year! I am lucky to live in the countryside. I understand why many teenagers in cities might not think about becoming birdwatchers, but there are actually many birds to see, especially in places with lots of green areas. I also think that birdwatching clubs should try to get more young people interested in this hobby. Everyone needs to connect with nature, no matter their age, and it doesn’t have to cost much money.'

Text: "I started playing football when I was 7 years old. I would hurry home from school to play with other kids. I loved it, and after some time, I became a good player. My family knew I often got excited about new hobbies and then stopped them, so they thought I would do the same with football. But that never happened. I even dreamed of playing football professionally when I grew up. The chance came sooner than I expected. I played in local tournaments, and one referee saw that I was a talented player. He asked the manager of a professional women’s club to watch me play. After that, she invited me to join her club. I was surprised at first because I didn’t know young girls could join women’s clubs. But the manager liked my skills, and I started training regularly with a big club when I was 13 years old. I improved a lot after that. Still, some people were not sure I would become a star player, which made me a little sad. But my coach encouraged me to be myself and believe in myself. He even let me play in one of the club’s championship matches earlier than I thought I would! I ran harder than ever because I didn’t want to let my teammates down. Then, by chance, I scored the winning goal. Even with a large crowd, I could hear my coach cheering for me, and after the match, my team carried me around the field. It was amazing! Since then, I have scored many more winning goals! Next month, my coach and I are organizing a football tournament in my area. The goal is to get teenagers interested in football and give them a chance to meet other players from my club. It will show them what a professional environment is like and encourage them to believe they can play for a top team if they work hard. My advice to them will be the same as my coach gave me – there will be good times, but also some bad times. I’ve had very few bad times, though, so I feel lucky!"

Text: 'In recent years, one of the most interesting changes in education in the UK and around the world has been the push to get new students involved in research as early as possible. This change shows that research is not just for famous scholars at old universities or scientists who are discovering new things in fields like medicine. Instead, research is a natural way to build knowledge and skills. The skills you learn from research will help you not only in your studies but also in your future jobs, as they teach you how to think about the world and how to approach your work.

As a student, you contribute to knowledge. You do not just learn and repeat what others say; you create new knowledge. Creating knowledge starts with asking questions instead of just accepting things as they are. You might wonder: Why? How? When? What does this mean? What if things were different? How does it work in this situation? What should we think about the facts, opinions, or beliefs we are given? Why is this important? These questions are at the heart of what we call research.

Research can be seen as a range of activities. On one end, there is complex, groundbreaking research done by highly trained experts, which leads to significant changes and new knowledge. However, research can also start from simple questions and everyday inquiries that involve careful work and thoughtful questioning about issues, practices, and events. Most students have always been researchers in some way. You have likely done research for school projects or answered questions at work since you started. You have asked questions that led you to investigate topics, whether it was about planning a holiday, growing plants, fixing things at home, training a pet, finding the right music system, or shopping online.

In college and higher education, it is expected that you will have a curious mind, identify problems and questions, critically explore and evaluate information, and create your own responses and knowledge to contribute to discussions. Some students may find this challenging because, in some cultures, knowledge is seen as fixed, and learning comes from listening to teachers and texts. It might feel disrespectful to question established knowledge or authority, and you may think you should be told what is important to learn. However, in higher education in the UK, US, much of Europe, and Australasia, questioning established knowledge and authorities is encouraged.

This process of inquiry and knowledge creation can seem overwhelming. Critical thinking is especially important in research. The research done by others is valuable for students, academics, and professionals, but we need to engage with it, think critically, and test it. We should not just accept everything we read as true; instead, we must analyze whether the information is logical, well-reasoned, and supported by evidence. We should avoid blindly trusting the facts and information we receive from others.'

Text: 'Cities have always been important places for ideas and creativity. In the 18th century, coffee houses in London were popular spots where people discussed science and politics. In modern Paris, cafés on the Left Bank were where artist Pablo Picasso talked about new art. However, living in a city can be difficult. The same London cafés that encouraged discussion also helped spread diseases like cholera, and Picasso eventually moved to the countryside. Today, cities are known for their creativity, but they can also feel unnatural and overwhelming.

Scientists are now studying how city life affects our brains, and the findings are concerning. While it has been known that city life can be tiring, new research shows that living in cities can actually make us think less clearly. One major reason for this is the lack of nature in urban areas. Studies have shown that hospital patients heal faster when they can see trees from their windows. Even small views of nature can help our brains because they give us a break from the busy city life.

This research comes at a time when more people than ever are living in cities. Instead of living in open spaces, we are packed into concrete areas, surrounded by many strangers. It has become clear that these crowded environments can affect our mental and physical health and change how we think. For example, when walking down a busy street, our brains have to pay attention to many things: people walking, busy traffic, and confusing street layouts. These small tasks can tire us out because cities are full of distractions that require us to constantly shift our focus. This process of deciding what to pay attention to takes a lot of mental energy.

In contrast, natural environments do not require as much mental effort. This idea is called attention restoration theory, developed by psychologist Stephen Kaplan. He suggested that being in nature can help restore our attention. Natural settings have things that naturally attract our focus but do not cause stress, unlike loud noises like police sirens. In nature, our minds can relax and recharge.

Long before scientists studied this, philosophers and landscape designers warned about the negative effects of city life and sought ways to include nature in urban areas. Parks, like Central Park in New York, provide a break from city life. A well-designed park can improve brain function quickly. While people have tried many methods to boost brain performance, such as energy drinks or changing office designs, nothing seems to work as well as simply walking in nature.

Given the many mental challenges caused by city life, we must ask: Why do cities keep growing? And why do they remain centers of creativity, even in the digital age? Recent research from the Santa Fe Institute shows that the same crowded features of cities that can hurt our attention and memory—like busy streets and close contact with many people—are also linked to innovation. Scientists believe that the ‘concentration of social interactions’ is key to urban creativity. Just as the crowded streets of 18th-century London led to new ideas, the busy environment of 21st-century Cambridge, Massachusetts, helps it thrive as a center for technology. On the other hand, less crowded areas may produce fewer new ideas over time. 

The challenge is to find ways to reduce the negative effects of city life while keeping its unique advantages. Because, as the saying goes, there will always be a moment when someone says: ‘I’m tired of nature; take me to the city!’'

**Simplified Text:**

Where should we look for the mind? This question may seem strange because we usually think that thinking happens inside our heads. Today, we have advanced brain imaging techniques to support this idea. However, I believe that studying the mind should not be limited to just what is inside our bodies. There is a lot of evidence, from ancient times to now, showing that objects, as well as our brain cells, play a role in how we think. 

From an archaeological perspective, it is clear that tools, jewelry, carvings, clay tokens, and writing systems have all been important in human evolution and the development of our minds. Therefore, I suggest that what is outside our heads can also be part of our minds. It is easy to see why people connect the mind with the brain. Most of what we know about the mind comes from studying people in isolation from their surroundings. This makes sense for neuroscientists who use brain scans, but it often overlooks the fact that much of our thinking happens outside our heads. 

I do not want to deny the importance of the brain in thinking, but I want to highlight that the mind is more than just the brain. It is more useful to explore the idea that human intelligence extends beyond our bodies into culture and the material world. This is where my new theory, called Material Engagement Theory (MET), comes in. MET looks at how objects can help us think and how they become part of our bodies, like when we use clay to make numbers or use a stone to create a tool. It also examines how these interactions have changed over time and what those changes mean for our thinking.

This approach gives us new insights into what minds are and how they work by changing our understanding of the role of objects in thinking. For example, think of a blind person using a stick. Where does this person’s self begin? The connection between the blind person and the stick shows how minds and objects can be linked, and it illustrates the flexibility of the human mind. By using the stick, the blind person can turn touch into a form of sight, and the stick becomes part of their body in a way. 

The blind person’s stick reminds us that human intelligence can change significantly by using new technologies. I see the human mind as a work in progress, always evolving. It is important to remember that, no matter what form the “stick” has taken throughout history—whether it is a simple stone tool or a modern smartphone—its main purpose is to connect us to the world. 

Through the “stick,” humans explore and understand their environment, and they also find new ways to move forward. This is different from how monkeys use sticks to get food. For humans, “sticks” help us satisfy our curiosity. This special ability to engage with material culture explains why humans create things more than any other species, and how those things shape our minds. I call this metaplasticity—our minds are flexible and change as we interact with the material world. I want to emphasize the importance of material objects in understanding the mind. MET provides a new way to see how different types of material culture, from ancient tools to modern technology, have influenced who we are and how we think. While the idea of technology changing our minds may sound futuristic, humans have been using it since the beginning of our existence.

Text: "Few inventions have changed the course of civilization as much as photography. This is especially true in the United States, where photography quickly became part of American culture at all levels – from practical and scientific uses to industrial and artistic ones, as well as a new world of entertainment that came with the camera. Historians say that photography is one of the greatest contributions of the United States to the visual arts. In no other art form has American work been so significant. This is a bold statement, but it shows how photography has become central to American thought and art. To fully appreciate its impact, we need to look at its beginnings in the mid-19th century. 

Why was this new art so attractive? First, photography was a mechanical process that matched a growing interest in technology, reflecting a national attitude that accepted change. Just as steam power, railroads, and electricity made communication and travel easier, photography brought the wonders of the world into homes in a stunning way. Second, the camera became the preferred tool for expressing identity, allowing people to create images for public viewing in a country where personal and national identities were always being formed and reformed. Third, the camera has been very important for families, providing a way to keep a record of their lives, even if that record is somewhat idealized. Finally, the realistic nature of photographs matched the trend towards realism in American art, which focused on everyday life.

Every photograph draws attention to something specific, showing what the photographer wants us to see. The fact that a photograph is made by a machine, rather than drawn by hand, gives it a unique quality: photographs are records of events, people, and things; they show at least what was in front of the camera, giving them a sense of objectivity. However, because each photograph is taken by a specific person, it also carries a personal point of view. We might look at a photograph and think we understand its meaning, especially if we recognize the subject. This is why photography has often been called a ‘universal language’. But the meaning of a photograph is more complicated than that. 

Few things in front of us – whether a person, object, or event – have their own meaning. No image is presented to us without some context that shapes our understanding of it, such as a caption in a newspaper, a layout in a magazine, or its position in a gallery or book. To understand a photograph historically, we need to consider its purpose and role in its culture: Why did the photographer take the picture? How did people first see it? Additionally, the same image might be viewed in different places and times, and its meaning would change accordingly.

For a long time, the importance of the camera to artists was not widely recognized, but today it is well understood. In recent decades, starting with U.S. artist Andy Warhol’s use of photographs in his paintings and silk screens, artists have been including photographs in their work in many ways. In summary, photographic vision has become an essential part of painting in art history, not something separate from it."

In 1890, William James, an American philosopher and doctor, defined psychology as the "science of mental life." This definition is still useful today. Everyone has a mental life, so we have some understanding of what this means. Although we can study mental life in rats, monkeys, and humans, it is still a complex idea. James focused mainly on human psychology, which he believed included basic elements like thoughts, feelings, the physical world, and how we know about these things. Our knowledge is mostly personal and comes from our own experiences, which may or may not be influenced by scientific facts.

Because of this, we often make judgments about psychological issues based on our own experiences. We act like amateur psychologists when we share our opinions on complicated psychological topics, such as whether brainwashing works or why people behave in certain ways. Problems can arise when two people understand things differently. Formal psychology tries to provide methods to determine which explanations are most likely correct in different situations. Psychologists help us separate subjective thoughts, which can be biased, from objective facts.

Psychology, as defined by William James, is about the mind and brain. While psychologists study the brain, they do not yet fully understand how it works in relation to our feelings, hopes, and behaviors. It is often difficult to study the brain directly, so psychologists learn more by observing behavior and forming hypotheses about what happens inside us. A challenge in psychology is that scientific facts should be objective, but the mind's workings are not easily observable. We can only understand them indirectly through behavior.

Studying psychology is similar to solving a crossword puzzle. It requires evaluating and interpreting clues, which must come from careful observation and accurate measurement. These observations need to be analyzed rigorously and interpreted logically. Psychology often involves complex interactions, and understanding them requires advanced techniques and theories. Like any other science, psychology aims to describe, understand, predict, and learn how to influence the processes it studies. When these goals are met, psychology can help us understand our experiences and apply this knowledge to improve people's lives.

Psychological research has been useful in many areas, such as improving teaching methods, designing safer machines, and helping people express their feelings better. Although psychological questions have been discussed for centuries, they have only been studied scientifically for the last 150 years. Early psychologists used introspection, or self-reflection, to answer psychological questions. They aimed to identify mental structures, which is still important today. However, introspection has limitations. As Sir Francis Galton noted, it only allows us to see a small part of what the brain does automatically. William James compared trying to understand the mind through introspection to "turning up the gas quickly enough to see how the darkness looks." Today, psychologists prefer to base their theories on careful observations of others' behavior rather than on their own experiences.

In a storehouse in a regular business park in Michigan, USA, there is a place that shows the failures of consumer products – the opposite of the positive, success-focused world of modern marketing. Here, you can find unusual items like A Touch of Yogurt shampoo and Breakfast Cola, which were not popular. This collection, owned by a company called GfK, is informally known as the Museum of Failed Products. It displays products that were taken off the market because very few people wanted to buy them. The owner, Carol Sherry, believes that each product has its own sad story involving designers, marketers, and salespeople.

What is most surprising about this museum is that it exists as a successful business. You might think that any good manufacturer would keep a collection of their failed products. However, the executives who visit the museum show that this is not common. They often avoid thinking about their failures and do not keep samples of their unsuccessful products. The museum itself started by accident. Robert McMath, a former marketing professional, wanted to create a ‘reference library’ of consumer products, not just failed ones. Starting in the 1960s, he began buying samples of every new item he could find. He did not realize that most products fail. By collecting new products without discrimination, he ended up with mostly unsuccessful ones.

Today’s culture of optimism may explain why many products ended up in the museum. Each product likely went through meetings where no one noticed it would fail. Even if they did, marketers might invest more money into a failing product to try to save face. Little effort is made to understand why these products failed, and everyone involved may choose to forget about it.

This focus on optimism is especially strong in the growing ‘self-help’ industry. A common idea here is ‘positive visualization’: if you imagine things going well, they are more likely to happen. Some researchers believe that our ability to see the positive side is so important for survival that it has become part of our nature. Neuroscientist Tali Sharot has found that a healthy mind may be designed to see good outcomes as more likely than they really are. Her research suggests that well-balanced people often have an overly optimistic view of their ability to influence events, unlike those who are depressed.

But how effective are these ‘positive fantasies about the future’? Psychologist Gabriele Oettingen and her team have studied this question. Their findings are surprising: spending time thinking about how well things could go can actually reduce most people’s motivation to reach their goals. For example, groups of people who were encouraged to imagine having a very successful week at work ended up achieving less.

Psychologist Carol Dweck believes that our experiences with failure depend on our beliefs about ability. Dweck says that people with a ‘fixed mindset’ think ability is something you are born with, while those with a ‘growth mindset’ believe it can develop through effort and challenges. People with a fixed mindset find failure very scary because it shows they did not meet expectations. For example, a sports star who thinks of himself as a ‘natural’ may not practice enough and fail to reach his potential. On the other hand, people with a growth mindset see failure as a sign that they are pushing their limits. Dweck compares this to weight training: muscles grow stronger when they are pushed to their limits, where they tear and heal. The deeper message is that having a growth mindset is a happier way to live, whether or not it leads to success.
