Doug Allan films wild animals in cold places. If you have ever been amazed by videos of polar bears in a nature documentary, it is likely that he filmed them. He says his favorite temperature is -18°C. Allan trained as a marine biologist and commercial diver. Diving was his first passion, where he learned how to survive in cold environments. His big opportunity came when a TV crew arrived in Antarctica, where Allan was working, to film a wildlife documentary. "I ended up taking the crew to different places, and after 48 hours, I realized that being a wildlife cameraman was perfect for me: travel, adventure, underwater," he explains. He is now a well-known cameraman and has worked on many important TV wildlife series.

"I started at a good time. When I began, very few people had been to Antarctica. There were people who filmed coral, elephants, and chimpanzees. I became known as the cold man. It felt like there were many amazing scenes waiting to be filmed." The camera and communication technology were very simple when he started 35 years ago. "It is much easier to film today. Back then, if you shot something, you had to remember it. Now, with digital technology, you can film a lot and see it right away. You had to think about what shots you needed next and what you missed. You filmed less because film was very expensive. Today, you can have too much material."

"My experience in cold conditions is valuable. I know how to handle it. I have spent so much time on sea ice that it feels normal to me. I do get cold toes, but the poles are healthy places. There are no leeches, diseases, or mosquitoes." Allan says that wildlife filming has many successes, but also failures and embarrassing moments. Once, he was in the Orkneys to film kittiwakes, but he could not identify the birds.

Recently, Allan got permission to film for a major TV series in Kong Karls Land, a group of islands in the Arctic Ocean. He did not expect it to be easy. It is a place with polar bears and is only for the bravest or most foolish people. In April, it is usually -32°C, the wind is strong, and carrying cameras in deep snow is very difficult. After walking for five or more hours a day and watching polar bear dens in the snow for 23 days, Allan had only seen one mother bear and her cub. However, on day 24, he felt like he was in the world of bears, moving at their speed and using their senses. 

"We find a new hole and wait. We move around to stay warm. After five hours of watching, I catch a quick glimpse that I almost miss. But the camera is focused on the hole, and I quickly look through the viewfinder. Nothing happens for a couple of seconds, and then I see a black nose. The nose becomes a muzzle, then a full head, and in less than a minute, she has her front legs out and is resting on the snow in front of the hole. She looks at me but is not scared. Just as I think it can't get better, she slides down the slope. I think she is enjoying it," he recalls, adding that two cubs then appeared at the den entrance. "It is clearly their first view of the world. It is showtime on the slopes, and we have front-row seats."

Now, Allan wants to make his own film about climate change in the Arctic, talking to the people who live there and see its effects firsthand. He believes he could create an extraordinary documentary.

In 2004, Pen Hadow became the first person to walk to the North Pole alone without getting supplies along the way. This journey involved swimming in extremely cold waters and facing dangers like frostbite and polar bears. Just eight months later, he also reached the South Pole. Now, he is back in the Arctic, getting ready for an even bigger adventure. Explorers are confident and determined people, and this time, there is a lot at stake. Pen and two colleagues will go on a three-month, 1,000-kilometre trek to the North Pole to measure the thickness and density of the ice. No one has done this before, and he knows the results will be very important for scientists. This will give a clear picture of how global warming is affecting the ice in the polar region.

Pen was prepared for this work from a young age. His father’s old nanny, who had worked for the famous polar explorer Scott of the Antarctic, took care of him. She toughened him up by sending him out into the Scottish mountains during storms with very few clothes. His father also inspired his love for adventures in cold places, and Pen developed great physical strength. 

Pen is married to Mary, who loves horses and shares his passion for the outdoors. She helps run his polar guide business and worries more about him when he is at home. She once raced against him in a famous mountain event, where she and her horse finished an hour ahead of him. Pen and Mary live in the countryside with their two children. He finds it harder to be away from them this time. When he last left, his children were one and five years old, and he made a mistake in how he said goodbye. He told his son to take care of his mother and sister, which made the boy very worried. Because of this, Pen plans to have little contact with them while he is in the Arctic, as he believes it will be better for them.

In the days before he leaves, he is carefully preparing his equipment. He knows that out on the ice, it is very difficult to fix things or do anything complicated. He will be joined by Ann Daniels, a leading polar explorer, and Martin Hartley, the expedition photographer. They will have a support crew of six people who will fly in supplies. Pen feels that being part of a team can be stressful for him, and he is also thinking about his age. He will turn 47 soon and feels he has not trained enough. He often finds that organizing things takes more time than he expects, which makes him worried about his physical limits.

Pen believes that his mission connects exploration with the search for knowledge that motivated earlier explorers. He admits that reaching the North Pole was a personal goal and not very useful to anyone outside the polar adventure community. This time, however, scientists will benefit from the data they collect, and they want to involve as many people as possible in understanding what is happening in the Arctic Ocean. He feels this work is important, and they are the only ones who can do it. He believes their unique skills, which may seem strange in everyday life, are now very relevant and useful.

Text: 'I took a year off. What was I going to do? Being a successful Olympian is a wonderful experience. I had the opportunity to do more writing and TV work, and to speak to businesses and schools. Although I enjoyed these different activities, I didn’t have anything competitive to focus on. I wanted to stay in shape so I could compete for an Olympic spot if I felt inspired again. So, I entered marathons and triathlons. That should have been enough, but I kept thinking about TV presenter Ben Fogle’s invitation: “Do you want to row across the Atlantic with me?” I have always loved rowing and the feeling of the boat moving through the water. I started to miss that feeling, but I wasn’t ready to train every day. Still, I wanted some kind of competition. I asked some of my rowing friends if they wanted to join the race, but they weren’t very excited. I knew that if I entered the race, even though it was called an adventure, I would want to win. Would rowing with Ben give me the best chance to win? No. But being an underdog without pressure was appealing. I contacted Ben. He was going to join the race anyway and had managed to gather the large entry fee and deposit for a boat, making the race a real possibility. We talked about the other costs; the boat and equipment would cost £70,000 – a lot of money. We thought we had a better chance than most, but we still needed to work hard to secure it. Besides the race costs, I also had to think about the money I would lose by being away from home. Speaking at business conferences is one of the best ways to earn money as a retired athlete. It feels good that people are interested. But I find it hard to talk about my past achievements without having a new goal. Joining the race would mean I wouldn’t just talk about what I did before. I would actually be doing something again: rowing across the Atlantic. I learned a lot while planning this adventure, but one of the biggest lessons was to appreciate the easy life of a full-time athlete. My preparation for the Olympics was tough, and my life was focused on getting in the best shape; but looking back, it was quite simple. Yes, I trained almost every day, but the training program was set, and there were doctors and dieticians. I was worried about how people would see me racing with a TV presenter. I thought it might look like I just wanted to be on TV, or else I would have chosen a better partner to win the race. My worries faded as we prepared. The Atlantic Rowing Race is about more than just rowing. It’s also about mental strength. Ben had completed the difficult Marathon des Sables, spent a lot of time at sea, and lived on a deserted island for a year. However, he couldn’t row well. I was surprised by how little he understood about rowing, and he was shocked by my lack of patience. I could have been more understanding, but I felt it was important to tell Ben how much he needed to improve. I should have realized that this would be his level when I agreed to race with him.'

Text: 'Just over a year ago, I left my job to work with huskies in the Arctic Circle in northern Finland. At 26, I felt restless. I dreamed of cold, empty landscapes, perhaps because I was tired of the noise and crowds of London. I found a small company run by Anna McCormack and her husband, Pasi Ikonen, in Finnish Lapland. They agreed to hire me as a husky dog handler for a busy winter season. From December to February, they take many tourists on sled rides pulled by huskies across the ice and snow, for trips that can last from one hour to five days. They started with six dogs, but soon had more than 100. Recently, they took over a second property called the 'wilderness farm,’ which they described as a beautiful but basic place with unreliable electricity and no running water. They told me I could join the team for three months if I understood what I was getting into. 'The hours are long, the conditions are tough, and the work is very physical,’ they said. I started packing right away. 

November 6, London: On my flight, I stared at a page with more than 100 pictures of huskies. I was supposed to memorize their names before I arrived, but I felt distracted and nervous. I put the page down and looked out the window instead. It is said that spring moves north at about 26 km per day, bringing flowers and leaves. However, I felt like I was seeing winter moving south, with rivers freezing over.

November 7, Helsinki and Hetta: The bus ride north was everything I hoped for. We drove through endless dark forests with thin trees weighed down by snow, stopping sometimes to let reindeer pass. I arrived at the farm after dark, and as soon as I walked in, I was given a pair of boots and sent out into the cold. 'Do you want to be thrown in at the deep end?’ Anna asked. It was a rhetorical question. I followed the sound of barking, which grew louder as I reached the dogsheds. Three people were running back and forth, pulling the huskies out and harnessing them to sleds. The dogs were very excited, straining against their ropes. I could barely introduce myself, but the others were too busy to talk. I stood to the side and petted one of the quieter dogs. Someone waved at me impatiently – 'Get in!’ – and I almost fell into the nearest sled. A command was shouted, and with a jerk, we were off into the dark, with only a headlamp for light.

November 15, Hetta: It didn’t take long to become part of the husky guides, but first, I faced a tough questioning about what I could do for the group. 'Are you useful?’ Anna asked. I was confused. I didn’t know. Further questions showed that I was not very useful: I had never driven a snowmobile, hadn’t done woodwork since school, and had never chopped anything with an axe. 'You do have a driving license?’ someone asked finally. I nodded, feeling relieved. The basics of dog-sledding are easy to learn: lean into the corners, put both feet on the brake to stop, and, no matter what, don’t let go of the handlebar. But everything else seemed complicated. Simple tasks like feeding and watering the dogs became hard in freezing conditions. A bowl of water would freeze quickly, so we had to make a 'soup’ of meat in hot water for the dogs. By the end of my first week, my head was full of instructions, and my muscles ached from pulling heavy sleds – and from being pulled around by excited huskies. But I felt proud. 'I can chop with an axe, hammer a nail, and use a circular saw,’ I emailed my friends. 'In the snow.’'

Text: 'On that day, as Radcliffe ran past the finish line, reporters gathered to understand her amazing performance. It was noted that her time would qualify her to compete in the men's marathon at the world championships in Paris. Curious journalists asked her about a special natural treatment, emu oil, which Olympic gold medallist Cathy Freeman had recommended to help heal Radcliffe's injuries from an accident when she ran into a bike while training. Radcliffe says that the achievement didn’t fully sink in at the time. Looking back, she realizes it was a big deal, but she felt it was just what she was meant to do that day. She and her support team had decided not to set limits on their goals. Their motto was: no limits. During the race, Gary Lough, Radcliffe's husband and coach, was in a car with her support team, listening to the radio coverage. Next to him was Gerard Hartmann, her physiotherapist. After 16 kilometers, Radcliffe's agent wondered if she could keep up her fast pace, worried it might make her drop out of the race. Hartmann was angry at this concern, but he understood that anyone who didn’t know how fit she was might think it was risky to start so quickly. With 800 meters left, Radcliffe started to calculate. She realized she could finish in under 2 hours and 16 minutes if she crossed the line in less than three minutes. She had already run 41 kilometers at a fast speed but still managed to sprint the last part in 2 minutes and 25 seconds. At the finish, she thought, ‘I can run faster than that.’ She remembers the race director, Dave Bedford, saying he never thought anyone would come close to that time for a while. Radcliffe thought, “I will come back and do it next year.” Unfortunately, that did not happen. After the race, everyone wanted to know how an athlete with such an unusual running style had beaten the skilled East African runners. Hartmann had worked with Radcliffe for weeks, giving her daily sessions to help with the 250-300 kilometers she ran each week. He said, ‘I’ve worked with 63 Olympic medallists, and no one could handle the level of pain she could. She would make me work hard because I had to go deep into her muscles, and I would have to ice my thumbs afterwards because I was in so much pain.’ Hartmann described traveling 13 hours from his home in Ireland to Radcliffe's training base in France, only to be greeted by her husband saying, ‘Gerard, you’re 15 minutes late, Paula's waiting.’ There was no ‘Hello Gerard, do you want a cup of tea?’ As soon as he arrived, she was ready for a two-hour session. ‘Paula would push you to your limits. That’s what made her so good.’ During that time, Hartmann spent so much time with Radcliffe that his other athletes became upset. Can Radcliffe explain why no one has come close to her record? ‘Not really. I trained very hard, but there are people who are more talented. I thought it would happen with Mary Keitany (two-time London marathon winner). Maybe it’s because people are racing against each other instead of racing against themselves.’ What does she mean? ‘That mental attitude of never slowing down, even when you have the race won, probably helped me because I never thought, “I can relax now.” It was always: “keep pushing as hard as you can.” Radcliffe did not know it then, but that marathon was the peak of her career. She would never run that fast again. However, she inspired many women to take up long-distance running.'

Text: 'When my first cooking show, In Search of Perfection, was released, I was unsure how viewers and critics would react. There was a lot of talk about a food ‘revolution’ happening in Britain, and I believed we had created a series that contributed something new to this movement. However, I worried whether people would enjoy a cooking show that included not just techniques but also history, memories, and science. I watched the first episode with mixed feelings of happiness and fear. I didn’t need to worry. The success of the show led to many other interesting projects, including a book based on my experiences at my restaurant. Each project felt like a journey, whether into the past, the mind, or cooking techniques. I then wrote several books in a series called ‘Perfection’, each one linked to its own TV show. In these books, the journey was often physical, involving passports and travel plans. The latest book, In Search of Total Perfection, takes you around the world to meet amazing artisans, like a man who finds joy in making golden pasta that tastes better than any other. These artisans have spent years chasing their own ideas of perfection. Perfection is very personal. Even choosing which dishes to include in the series was difficult, and I knew I would disappoint some people by leaving out their favorites. I could imagine people asking, ‘Where’s steak and kidney pie and bread and butter pudding?’ However, after a long meeting with the TV production team, we finally created a list that included something for everyone. This experience reinforced my belief that everyone has their own idea of perfection, shaped by their emotions, memories, and surroundings. Despite the book’s title, I knew I wouldn’t claim that the recipes were the ‘best’. But I believed that by using my skills and knowledge, and by talking to food producers, artisans, chefs, and their customers, I could identify what made these dishes special. The dictionary defines ‘perfection’ as being perfect, but it also means improving through constant practice. Trying out ideas and changing them until you create something unique. The TV series allowed me to explore many foods, people, and places I had never seen before, and I was excited to connect food with memories because I started my career in the same way. Finding the best ingredients took me around the world. I had many adventures, like visiting a canning factory that was processing the wrong type of tomato and going to a dairy farm that did not meet our standards for perfection, which made us stop filming there! While refining each recipe, I ended up hand-milking a cow and using dry ice to make ice cream, cooking chicken in a hospital scanning machine, and almost burning my house down trying to get the oven hot enough for a real Neapolitan-style pizza.'

Text: 'We were still a long way from Marrakech when the van made a loud noise, swerved off the road into a field, and stopped. John got out and opened the engine cover. He looked at the engine for a long time with his hands in his pockets and a serious look on his face. “Actually, I don’t know what I’m doing,” he finally said, and he and Mum started to laugh. Bea was worried, “We can’t stay here forever,” she said. The field went on for miles. There was not much in it, just grass and many flowers, like poppies and daisies. “No, we can’t stay here forever,” I agreed, because it was best to support Bea. We got back into the van and waited for Mum and John to stop laughing. We sat by the road and watched John get smaller as he walked away to find someone who knew about cars. Mum lay down on the grass. “Tell us a story,” she said. Bea lay down next to her. “Go on, tell us a story.” So I told them about how the day before we left London, I heard two birds talking. I shared everything the birds talked about: breadcrumbs, other birds, the weather, and an argument over a worm. “That’s silly, no one understands bird language,” Bea said. My eyes felt wet. “I do.” But my voice didn’t sound sure. “Liar.” I felt embarrassed. How could I be lying if I remembered every word? The more I thought about it, the less sure I became. “Mum…?” But she had fallen asleep in the sun. John came back with three Moroccan boys who helped us push the van along the road to the hotel. Bea didn’t want to get out. The boys didn’t mind at all. They waved and smiled at her through the back windows. We followed John into a café. It was set back from the road and not far from where our van was parked. “It’s a hotel,” John whispered. “I think it might be a bit expensive.” “We’ll just have some tea,” Mum said, and we sat down in the shade. The tea they brought was made from mint leaves and was very sweet. Mum looked into the pot. “It’s like syrup in there,” she said. We stayed at the café all day while John looked sadly at the engine. “I guess it’s a miracle it got us this far,” he said as it began to get dark. Mum took blankets out onto the road. She made a bed for us in the hotel garden. It felt nice to sleep on the ground. “I’ll have to get us towed into Marrakech,” John said from the other side of Mum. Half an hour later, we were in a truck watching our van being pulled behind with John driving. At first, Bea didn’t want to move, so John picked her up and put her in the truck. Now she sat in the front with the driver. I kept wondering how we would get home now that our van had to be towed everywhere. I thought it might be easier to take a boat straight to London. Then I must have fallen asleep.'

Text: 'Lucy was talking at the welcome party in the hotel ballroom to two other pianists who were also at the Prague Classical Music Festival. Unlike her, they were not competing: a guy from Tokyo and a girl from a European city whose name Lucy didn’t quite catch over the noise. They were both about ten years older than her and spoke good English. They talked about the pieces they were playing, where they had traveled recently, and where they were going next. “I think I'm doing Tanglewood this summer,” Lucy told them. It sounded impressive, but she didn’t really want to go to the Tanglewood festival. She often felt overwhelmed by the concerts and competitions that took her around the world and made her miss so much school that she wasn’t officially enrolled anymore. Instead, she worked with different tutors from the University of San Francisco. She hadn’t even wanted to come to the Prague Festival, which only accepted fifteen pianists her age from around the world. Out of thousands of applicants, she had been chosen. There had been a party, and Lucy’s dad bought her a white-gold necklace with an L pendant to congratulate her. Her little brother Gus dreamed about being at the same festival one day. Grace Chang, her teacher, took Lucy out for a special dinner to plan her music pieces. The truth was, Lucy hadn’t even applied. Her mother had filled out the form and sent in the CD. “I didn't want you to be disappointed if you didn’t get in,” her mom had said. Lucy thought, “More like you didn't want to give me the chance to say no.” At that time, Lucy believed that making waves was the worst thing a person could do, and she didn’t even think about trying to get out of it. The guy from Tokyo leaned forward as if he had misheard her. “Tanglewood?” “Yeah.” “How old are you?” “Fifteen.” He exchanged a look with the girl, who said, “Wow.” Lucy hadn’t meant to brag. It was hard to know when she was just sharing her experiences and when she was showing off. “It's just part of this new youth-spotlight thing they're going to try...” “Excuse me,” the girl said, looking across the room as if she saw someone she needed to talk to. The guy stayed. “Have you ever been to Japan?” He had long, shaggy hair, like many musicians, to show they were music lovers but also a bit rebellious. “Once. When I was about eight.” He started to reply when Lucy's grandfather appeared at her side. “Lucy, let me introduce you to someone.” He took her arm and pulled her away from the conversation. “And don’t get too friendly with the competition.” “They're not the competition.” “Everyone is the competition.” Her grandfather took her around the room and made her talk to everyone he thought was important. Lucy smiled and nodded a lot, understanding only part of what was said. In the elevator to their suite after leaving the party, her grandfather turned to her. “You did well in there, Lucy. I’m proud of you. This is an important festival, and people are talking about you. They all know who you are.” She liked that part. Being someone important. Even if it meant some people were jealous or thought she was too young to get the attention she did. Being a concert pianist didn’t earn her any special respect from the kids she had gone to school with. Even her best friend, Reyna, didn’t know and wouldn’t care that she could play a Rachmaninov piece perfectly. But in places like this, she knew she mattered.'

Text: "‘It’s not good for you to spend so much time online. You need to get out into the real world,’ said Dad. It’s hard to argue with him, so I decided to see what experts say about this topic – and it’s quite interesting. Research shows that many teenagers who use social media have a wide circle of real-life friends, a good sense of identity, and are learning important technical skills for the digital age. Simon Miles, an e-safety expert, says ‘social networking is now a big part of growing up. Teenagers don’t just use media like adults do – they live in it. That’s not necessarily good or bad – it depends on how you use it.’ 

How does our social networking compare to what our parents did when they were young? Jim Matthews, a social media analyst, says it’s ‘like hanging out at the youth club, as parents did in their youth, to share jokes and catch up on news: a kind of virtual youth club.’ He believes it helps teenagers develop their identity away from their parents and learn to deal with teenage issues and connect with their peers. 

Psychologist Professor Keith Davidson says: ‘Adolescence is a time when you ask, who am I? Social networking can help you find your identity: you can share your favorite music or sports, discover what you like, and see that others have different views. Research shows that active social networkers are not as self-centered as those who don’t use social media.’ He adds that social media can help shy people: ‘Talking online can be easier than face-to-face, and it allows you to practice social skills in a less stressful way.’ 

Professor Andrew Phillips is studying how young people use social networking sites. He believes they can help quiet people with special interests connect with others who share those interests. ‘If you’re one of only a few people in your school who likes a certain type of music, you might feel alone. But if you find a social networking group of people like you, you can feel more connected and popular in a different way,’ he says. 

Pauline White, a digital education expert, shared something interesting: ‘It’s young people who find new interests online, join networks of similar individuals, and create their own content who are really using social networks well.’ She thinks social networking is becoming a creative tool: teenagers are making videos, podcasts, and blogs about what interests them. Photo-sharing sites are changing creativity. Passionate photographers can connect, learn skills, share images, and deepen their interests. ‘This all helps with job opportunities and will be useful in the workplace,’ she says. ‘Every business uses social media to sell and build brand awareness – and you need to know how it works to attract customers. For example, if you create a product and have 1000 friends on different social networks, they could all be potential customers. If you connect all those networks, you have your customer base.’ 

Teenagers who use social networking creatively will benefit when they become adults and enter the job market, agrees Matthews. ‘One great thing about many sites is the chance to work with others to create content and share it. Collaboration is an important skill in the 21st century and is key to being employable in a digital world.’"

Text: 'When most people think of a relaxing family vacation, they might not imagine a long trip across nine western states in the US and a Canadian province. However, my parents were not looking for a quiet time as they planned our summer vacation this year. My dad seemed determined to create what he thought was the perfect family bonding trip. “Not enough people do this anymore,” he and my mother said repeatedly before our vacation, while my twin brother and I exchanged worried looks, thinking, “There are probably good reasons why!” 

In mid-June, we packed our car with suitcases, coolers, and a mix of clothes for any weather. I was excited but knew I would miss my privacy for the next two weeks, although I had some ways to cope. With barely enough space left for us in the car, we began “The Family Great American Road Trip.” Leaving our big home for smaller places for the next five thousand miles, I wasn’t the only one wondering what we were getting into. 

We drove west through the Oklahoma panhandle. Even though we were still close to home, we had our share of adventures. We stopped for the night near a town in Oklahoma, under a sky full of stars, after almost being blown off the road by a dust storm. We quickly learned that cattle have the right-of-way on the road! The next day, we woke up early and continued our journey. I noticed a pattern: deserts turned into mountains. The days started to blend together, but each adventure was still unique. We left our footprints in the Great Sand Dunes and then went to Pagosa Springs, Colorado. The strong smell of sulfur in that friendly tourist town hinted at what we would experience later. 

At one point, as we climbed to our next stop, we learned that roads marked for Jeeps are best for Jeep drivers. We saw a mix of old and new everywhere we went. Dealing with construction traffic became normal. Disappointment turned to laughter when we took pictures by the huge “CLOSED” signs at the Four Corners Monument. We passed many wind farms on our way to Yellowstone National Park, where we watched the sunset over bear habitats near the roads. ‘Bear jams,’ where park volunteers helped manage traffic, were common as we drove through, especially when a bear crossed the road. Our close encounter with a bear (and a worried park ranger) gave us unforgettable memories. 

As we continued driving, life back home faded away, and even the hotel we stayed in, which had many problems, couldn’t dampen our excitement. It was an old, creaky building with no internet or cell phone service, but the views were amazing. After watching a rainstorm from our hotel in Canada, my family and I headed back south. My parents were right: you don’t need to go to a faraway place to find something special. It was a bit sad to be home again, but at least I hadn’t fought with my brother during our one hundred hours on the road! We had three thousand photos from our crazy journey to look through and remember. I knew that the best memories would be the unexpected and spontaneous moments.'

Rose Frost was sixteen years old and was going to live with her grandmother, Daisy. Rose's family was separating for two years. Her father, Jeff, had a job overseas, and her mother, Dahlia, would join him. Rose and her older sister, Amy, were staying in England. Amy would spend the next year finishing her last school courses, living under the care of the college Head. It was her final year at school, so it would not be fair for her to move. Amy was happy because she got the best room at the college, which had its own kitchen and study area. She also had free access to the Internet and phone. Jeff and Dahlia would keep an eye on Amy, whether she liked it or not. So, Rose was moving to her grandmother’s house.

Rose only had vague memories of her grandmother from holidays, and she had never known her grandfather. When Daisy offered Rose a place to stay, her parents were not excited about it, but Daisy insisted it was no trouble and wanted to get to know Rose again. Rose was not sure why her parents did not get along with her grandma, but there had been a disagreement in the past. Because of this, Rose had spent summers away from her only other family member. The last time Rose said goodbye to Daisy, she was only ten years old, but she remembered happy times.

Dahlia told Rose that living with Daisy would be interesting. Daisy was very social and loved to bring people together. Rose could expect dinner invitations, coffee mornings, and shopping trips within a week. The thought made her smile. Daisy was not a typical frail old lady; she seemed to go to more social events than anyone else. Before the move, Dahlia and Rose had a talk. Rose was sensible and mature for her age. She knew about healthy eating, staying fit, and getting enough sleep. But this time, Rose wanted one thing: her independence. Living with Daisy would meet her needs, but Rose wanted to play music loud, invite friends over, and go out without asking for permission every time. She wanted to avoid being nagged about homework or staying out late, and she did not want to be dragged around by her grandmother. Daisy understood.

Rose’s mother gave her a new touch-screen mobile phone with a video camera for emergencies only, as Dahlia insisted. Rose was very happy. They all agreed that it would be about trust. Daisy would trust Rose to act maturely, and Rose would trust Daisy not to be too strict. If either of them went too far, they would talk about it again.

Rose had never been a wild child. Her few school friends were similar, so her school reports were always good, and her exam results were excellent. This helped her a lot. In five weeks, Rose would start at a new school, meet new friends, and begin her life again. This would be her fourth senior school in five years, so she felt experienced. At least she knew this was the last time, as she would be starting her final two years at school. For Rose, it was a new moment in her life, a new piece in the puzzle that was her life.

Text: Charlotte Grainger shares that her primary school teacher was the first person to think she might write a novel. “I believed that writing a book would be a great achievement because it seemed like a big challenge. I didn’t know what other teenagers were doing, like competing in the Olympics. When I turned 13, I thought, ‘I should try this now.’ The novel she started at that age is now about to be published. “I recently told my former teacher about it, and she was surprised. She thought I would probably write a book when I was 30 or 40. I never thought that – I didn’t understand why I should wait to do something I might be good at.” 

It is a winter afternoon in the offices of Charlotte’s publishers. Even though I knew I was going to interview a 15-year-old girl about her book, I was still surprised to see a teenager sitting there. The book is a significant achievement: the story is confident and full of action. Nothing about it, except for the age of its main character, suggests that it was written by a teenager. A public relations representative is with us in case Charlotte needs support. But she doesn’t need any help. She is independent, with a bright face and a lively mind, but also a calmness that keeps her from being overly confident. 

Charlotte understands the limits of her youth. When I ask her about the complex moral questions in her book, she says, “I was trying to ask big questions, not answer them. I don’t have many life lessons to share with my readers,” she laughs. “I don’t think my age limits my understanding of the world, but I also don’t think I’m very wise. I was just interested in exploring the idea of taking responsibility.” 

She has a theory about teenagers and how they are often misrepresented in books aimed at them. She believes there are three types of teenagers shown in novels: the outsider who becomes accepted, the naïve teenager who knows little about the world, and the awkward teenager who struggles socially. Reading about these character types annoyed her. “What if you’re basically fine? There aren’t many stories about characters who aren’t lacking in some way. Some writers give the impression that teenagers can’t know who they are because they lack experience. When this idea is pushed on them, it can hurt their self-confidence.” 

Charlotte has always loved reading famous fantasy authors, but their books almost discouraged her from writing. “Books by my favorite fantasy writers explore deep topics about psychology and life. I wondered: is this what I need to do to write a good book, and am I really capable of it?” However, she appreciates a book called How Not to Write a Novel. “It tells you that if the reader starts to guess what will happen, the suspense is probably gone.” 

Some might say that Charlotte’s parents, both journalists, played a key role in getting her novel published. In fact, her father’s connection in publishing helped get her book read at first. She recognizes her good luck because it is hard for anyone to get a first novel read, no matter their age. “Every aspiring writer needs support and a bit of luck, but after that, you’re on your own. Ultimately, writers succeed or fail based on their talent, so I don’t take anything for granted,” Charlotte concludes.

Text: "‘Remember, speed is your friend, not your enemy,’ said Gareth, our instructor, as we looked down the ski slope. ‘Now, who wants to go first?’ The group looked nervous. Then one guy, David, who had some experience with freestyle ski-jumping, stepped forward and skied down the slope towards the jump. He hit the ramp quickly and flew into the air, arms waving. Even to us, it looked wrong. We held our breath. He landed hard, lost both skis, and flipped into the snow. ‘Remember,’ Gareth kindly told us, ‘speed can be unpredictable.’ Maybe freestyle skiing wasn’t for me. On past skiing holidays, I had enjoyed practicing turns in the snow. I wasn’t one of those teenagers who did tricks on ramps and half pipes in skate parks. I thought it looked fun, but I felt I would be laughed at if I tried to join them. Then my parents decided we would have a winter holiday at a freestyle skiing training center in the US. It had a big indoor area near the slopes, with trampolines and ski jumps covered in artificial snow. Students jumped, trying new tricks, and landed in foam pits – not a realistic way to prepare for the real slopes. After practicing indoors, students went outside to try their moves for real. ‘Progression is inevitable!’ the center’s slogan cheerfully told us. ‘Before places like this trained people, inexperienced ski jumpers would just go down the slopes and hope for the best,’ said Gareth. ‘But remember – if you land on the knuckle, you’ll be in trouble.’ The ‘knuckle’ is the flat area behind the jump before the slope gets steep again. If you land in the zone, you keep moving forward, which is safer. If you land on the flat, you stop suddenly, which hurts. So, speed is important. At first, it was hard to convince my body to ignore my fear and go straight towards the jump. My legs would almost go backward as I got close, so I landed on the knuckle. I didn’t fall, but by midday I felt exhausted. ‘You need to control the jump, not let it control you,’ said Gareth. Day two started on the trampolines. I thought I would hate being indoors, looking at the snowy mountains, but bouncing on the trampolines was fun. Some exercises copied moves we would make while ski-jumping, while others helped us learn ‘aerial awareness’ – knowing what your body was doing while spinning in the air. Gareth gave us tips. My ‘aerial awareness’ needed improvement – every time I tried, I only remembered the moment before take-off, and then I found myself in the foam cubes next to the trampoline. We went back to the mountain to try again. There were more mistakes before I finally landed correctly. Gareth seemed as happy as I was, and for a moment, I felt proud of achieving my goal. But that feeling didn’t last long. On the last run of the day, I made myself keep my speed up as I approached the jump, flew into the air, and landed correctly. Then I saw both skis sliding down the slope ahead, no longer attached to my feet."

Imagine you are on a rollercoaster at an amusement park. Your hands are sweaty with fear, and you grip the harness tightly. The ride suddenly stops, and you take a deep breath as the carriage slowly moves up. There is a pause, then a quick drop that makes your stomach feel like it’s in the air. You move fast forward, turn sharply to the left, and then go upside down. Your senses are confused, and you scream in fear. But you chose to be here, just like millions of others who pay to enter theme parks.

What surprises me is that amusement parks, with their thrilling rides, are a big business. To create the excitement and escape from reality that visitors want, there are large teams of creative engineers and designers working behind the scenes. The idea of being a "rollercoaster designer" might sound like a child's dream job, but it is actually very challenging. Designers must find the right mix of fun and fear while keeping riders safe. They also need to add new features to keep visitors interested.

While many people think rollercoasters are getting more intense, most of the techniques used today were actually invented by a US designer named John Miller in the early 1900s. During his time, there were fewer safety rules, and some rides were very extreme, which made many passengers uncomfortable. Now, designers have to follow the track designs made by special ride manufacturers.

I talked to three experts about rollercoasters. Professor Brendan Walker, a "thrill engineer," said, "The skill is in putting the pieces together." Dr. John Roberts, a member of the Royal Academy of Engineering, explained that it is important to quickly switch between feelings of excitement and safety so that riders feel thrilled but not scared. 

To create an amazing ride, the teams must come up with a strong story, like a space adventure or a jungle chase, that fits with new features like the tallest drops or the most twists. However, Professor Walker noted that, like in many creative jobs, experience and instinct are very important. Jeff Hornick, a senior director of theme park development, added that it helps to be passionate about thrills to understand what riders want and to test the rides before they open.

I asked the experts if rollercoaster designers will use new technology like virtual reality. Walker said we shouldn’t expect too much from it. He explained that while virtual reality can make rides look exciting, the real experience of being on a physical rollercoaster is what matters most, and that will continue to be important for many years.

At 25, Miranda Ellington has already done a lot as a choreographer, creating works for many theatres and dance companies. She also dances occasionally. I wonder why she manages to do both activities in her busy life. “Dancing again reminds me of what it’s like to be in the studio, following the orders of strict choreographers, and how stressful that can be. Choreographers can forget what it’s like to rehearse all day,” she tells me. As a choreographer, she teaches and enjoys working with young students. “A dancer who is just starting out is often open to trying new ideas. In some ways, working with students is easier than with professionals because they are willing to take risks. They want to succeed, but they don’t yet know their strengths and weaknesses. This lack of understanding helps them accept even tough criticism. They might challenge what I say sometimes, but I appreciate their honest feedback.” 

When Miranda begins working with a new group, she focuses on the dance steps, and the music guides her. “There may be a piece of music I don’t like, but I still make sure to create the best dance routine for it. If dancers don’t respond well to a certain composer’s music, it can be frustrating, but I still need to find solutions. I won’t go back and choose a new piece. Ideally, I’d like to be more experimental and have the option to switch to different pieces – it would help improve the mood when rehearsals get tough. Unfortunately, I’m often working on big productions where the music has already been decided by the composer, and I can’t change it.” 

Miranda does not want to be tied to one institution. “I think it’s important to keep meeting new people. However, I have to remember that the theatres and schools I work with have different methods and styles. So, I need to be ready to change how I work each time I go somewhere new, instead of just doing the same thing. This helps me avoid becoming too set in my ways.” 

The conversation shifts to a recent documentary about professional ballet dancers and choreographers. “There have been glamorous documentaries in the past that were misleading,” says Miranda. “This one tries to show the real life inside a dance company. There was a scene where a young dancer is getting many corrections, and I smiled because I recognized it. She knows she’s not getting it right but can’t make her body do what’s needed. It’s hard to watch but very real. The public often underestimates the amount of work and dedication needed in ballet.” 

I ask Miranda what makes a great ballet or dance production. “It’s when everything the company has worked on – the music, the costumes, the lighting, and the dancers – comes together. Perfection might be too much to expect, but aiming high is appreciated by audiences and can help you get away with a few mistakes. I’ve been part of productions where the dance steps are great, but something about the costumes or props is very distracting. That’s disappointing.” 

Miranda has done a wide range of work, so I wonder how she sees herself: is she a modern dance choreographer or a ballet specialist? “People want to label you, and I don’t understand that. There’s also a trend to focus on becoming an expert in a narrow area. I don’t follow that, but maybe one day I will be happy to be known for one thing. For now, I just want to expand my horizons.”

Text: 'A friend once asked me why I travel when I can see everything on television. I agreed that there are amazing things on TV, but why stay at home when there is so much to experience outside? This conversation inspired my crazy four-day trip and a film that encourages people to turn off their TVs. A friend was getting rid of his old sofa, which became the main part of the film. I added three wheels and some cables to it and connected them to old seatbelts over my shoulders. I put my luggage on the sofa and slept on it each night, even one night on the beach. Several friends joined me, helping to pull the sofa and encouraging me to keep going. I have walked on many trips in recent years, but this was something completely different. It was the longest distance I have ever walked, and I walked on main roads, which allowed me to stop at cafés and relax on the sofa with a cappuccino instead of sitting on a rock with my sandwiches blowing away. I often told people, “No, I’m not doing it for charity, and I’m not training for a marathon.” When someone at work asks about my weekend, I prefer to share how I dragged a sofa 100 miles across southern England rather than talk about the latest TV show. You can see the film on my website.'

Text: 'When I read about guided swimming trips in the sea around some small Greek islands, I felt excited. I had never tried organized group trips before. My brother, who I had traveled with before, was busy, so I thought a group holiday might be good for me. The man at the Greek port looked surprised when I asked for a single ferry ticket, as the islands are popular with families. I explained that I would not be alone for long; I would be joining ten others to swim around the small islands. Although he still looked confused, he smiled and showed me on board. Our group had exchanged emails before we left, but there was little time to talk before our first group swim. Our guides explained that a support boat would follow us the whole time and made sure we knew how to communicate with it. We did a short swim to divide us into speed groups, and then it was time for our first proper 1.5 km swim, which made me nervous. I had trained in my local pool and done some river swimming, but I had never swum long distances in the open sea. Soon, the waves got bigger, and I found myself at the back of the slow group, which was not where I wanted to be. I watched the faster swimmers move ahead like dolphins. I wanted to finish this first distance, and I was very happy when I finally did it on my own. The next days followed a routine: jumping in, finding a comfortable speed, and stopping to enjoy the scenery. As the swims got longer, my speed and enjoyment also increased. I felt like I didn’t need the support boat much anymore. I can hardly wait to come back next year.'

Text: "Being a flight attendant is not easy, but since I started this job, I have traveled to many places, from the US to Australia. I work with amazing people, have plenty of time off, and my life is always interesting – which makes it a great job for someone young like me! As a child, I went to a boarding school far from my family, so I often flew alone when school started and ended. Sometimes I felt lonely, so I asked the flight attendants if I could help serve meals to passengers, and some of them let me. This experience stayed in my mind when I wanted to leave my banking job and look for something new. 

At the interview, there were many young people, and many of us were hired. Like me, they were often well-qualified and changing careers. Before the interview, I practiced what to say – I wanted to say more than just that I loved to travel, as many others would say the same. Instead, I talked about my strengths and past work experience – and I got the job! I would recommend this kind of work to anyone because there are many reasons it is rewarding – but the free flights are not the main reason. Most airline staff work very hard, and there is a saying: ‘no one is finished until everyone is finished.’ It feels like a big family – even if we don’t see each other all the time, we are still close. When I’m not working, I don’t have to take work home. And if I do have difficult passengers, which is rare, I always know the flight will end soon, and I will probably never see them again!"

Text: "At the summer camp where I work, I really enjoy seeing the children succeed at things they never thought they could do. Most of the children already know how to swim and play table tennis before they arrive, but rock climbing is a new experience for many of them. Some children feel nervous, but after some encouragement, they agree to try, and they all reach the top in the end. This makes them feel great. 

At the beginning of the week, some children miss home. It is usually the ten- to thirteen-year-olds who feel this way the most. We do not let them use their mobile phones all the time. First, we tell them they can call home after lunch. When they ask again, usually after dinner, we say it is too late to call now and suggest they do it tomorrow. Most children feel better in a couple of days, and at the end of their week, they all come to us and thank us because they have had a great time.

It is not only the children who feel lonely. Sometimes, parents call us often to ask how their child is doing, which is not necessary. Often, their child is busy playing games or doing other activities, so we have to tell the parents to call back later. We also see some children who come dressed in expensive new clothes. These children often argue when we ask them to change into something more suitable, but soon they understand why it is important."

Text: 'Rock the Planet is a musical show where the actors also need to be good musicians. It opened in London last year after five years in the USA, where it won the title of ‘Best Musical’ four times! However, putting on the show with an all-British cast was difficult. The UK has more rules about how many performances young actors can do each week compared to the USA, where they can do more shows. Because of this, they needed twice as many actors in the UK. Fortunately, the director found many talented actors in the UK, and they have just won their first ‘Best Musical’ award. 

The theatre in London is bigger than the one in the USA, and it has been full every night, with everyone wanting to hear the songs that became popular in America. I met Jamie, an 11-year-old actor in the show. He said, ‘It’s amazing that I get paid to play, especially with a beautiful and expensive Gibson guitar.’ He shared how busy the young actors are. ‘We have regular school lessons every day at the theatre. The teacher is great, but I miss my old school friends.’ 

What do his friends think of the show? ‘Well, my whole class came! The theatre offers special ticket deals for schools. They loved it, and that made me feel really confident. My parents come when they can, but it’s expensive for them,’ he explained. When I mentioned that I also play guitar, Jamie found a spare one and invited me to play with him and the other young actors. We played a song called Days, which I didn’t know. Jamie helped me learn it, and I felt proud when I finally got it right. I was impressed by Jamie’s talent and wished I had similar skills. I was just trying to keep up and was glad the show’s director wasn’t there to hear my mistakes! 

While the young actors were already musicians, some playing several instruments, none had played in a band before. Luckily, they found it quite easy. Jamie said that the hardest part was looking natural when they first performed together. They were so focused that they forgot to smile! The show will be in London for another year, and it is definitely worth seeing.'
